hungary urged by the international monetary fund imf to cut its inflation more quickly may revise its 1998 economic policy plans finance minister peter medgyessy told the daily magyar hirlap on monday medgyessy who attends the world economic forum in davos told magyar hirlap that he had talks with imf deputy chief executive officer stanley fisher there stanley recognized the results of hungary 's two-year-old economic stabilisation programme by which the country substantially reduced its budget and current account deficits but added that hungary should reduce inflation more quickly medgyessy said `` following this i had the idea that perhaps we should work with alternative inflation plans when we prepare the 1998 budget draft '' medgyessy said `` one would calculate with the originally planned five percent cut for 1998 while the other with an even larger reduction '' he added hungary cut inflation to 23.6 percent in 1996 from 29.2 percent in 1995 and targets 16 to 18 percent for 1997 -- budapest newsroom 36 1 327 4040

downward pressure on the czech crown has subsided following a series of czech national bank cnb moves but analysts warned on tuesday that another attack on the currency is likely as the cnb measures are eased after months of rock-solid stability the crown came under fire last week from short-selling especially by foreign investors that pushed it to record lows of more than five percent below its basket parity prompting the cnb to intervene for the first time in more than a year the cnb said the crown 's fall was due to fluctuations of several foreign currencies and not for fundamental reasons adding that the bearish pressure has subsided this week but analysts said they expect another attack on the crown to begin once the central bank begins to loosen its grip regardless of the reason behind the first attempt `` what tends to happen in situations like this is that you get a second attack ... and i think you have to expect that '' said pavel pinkava a london-based currency dealer at nomura international pavel sobisek of zivnostenska banka in prague agreed `` the cnb showed a strong commitment to keep the crown at current levels but similar attacks on the crown look quite probable for the future '' the crown was steady at around 2.0 percent below parity of the central bank 's mark/dollar basket in tuesday afternoon trading from -3.8 percent on friday in an attempt to ward off bearish investors the central bank last friday raised its lombard rate to 50 percent from a previous 14 percent and followed up with a rise in repo rates to 45 percent from 12.9 percent analysts said the moves may have cost the central bank as much as 1 billion but they appeared to have had their desired effect banks have raised rates and the crown has moved closer to parity if the central bank continued to stand its ground it should win the war and beat back the tide of weaker crown sentiment analysts said `` the cnb has got to stand tough right now it is under government pressure over the economy but if it holds on it can withstand another wave and win this battle '' said one local dealer `` over the next couple of weeks the market will be pretty quiet and then there will be a final attack which i think will resolve itself in favour of the central bank and then they investors will walk away '' he added nomura 's pinkava agreed he said the central bank would have to hold rates at current levels for two to three weeks but that in the end the central bank should come out on top `` at the end of the day these crises often resolve themselves in favour of the central bank especially the first few times investors attack and especially in this market which is n't that deep '' he said -- prague newsroom 420-2-2423-0003

the head of investment analysis at credit suisse private banking said he thought swiss interest rates would move sideways for the rest of the year before rising slightly in 1998 swiss interest rates seem near a low point in this business cycle alexander galli told the finanz und wirtschaft newspaper in an interview published on saturday `` but the leeway for rates on the long end to go down does not seem completely exausted because the swiss economy will hardly leave the stagnation phase in 1997 and inflation is less than one percent '' he said real long-term rates of 2 to 2.5 percent are still relatively high while one percent seems close to the lower limit in the money market he said `` i thus expect a sideways movement of money and capital market rates in switzerland that could lead to a slight increase next year this is also true if the economy starts growing again in 1998 and inflation fears perhaps arise '' he said `` but i do n't see a significant change in interest rates because marked increases are not expected in either the united states or germany '' he added galli said the discount rate was already at an extraordinarily low level of 1.0 percent but it was possible the swiss national bank would cut it again `` a further reduction -- for example to 0.5 percent -- would not change anything about monetary policy given the massive expansion of money on offer already but would show the national bank 's will to do its utmost to support the ... swiss economy `` if it does this it has at most symbolic value because demand for discount credits has never had much significance for monetary policy '' he said -- zurich newsroom +41 1 631 7340

the world trade organisation wto established a dispute settlement panel to rule on a u.s. complaint against turkey 's 25 percent tax on box office receipts generated by the showing of foreign films a wto spokesman said the united states told the wto dispute settlement body that turkey 's municipality tax discriminated against foreign-origin films as no such tax was imposed on box office receipts from the showing of domestic films according to trade sources both the u.s. and turkish trade delegations said they hoped that a solution could be found to the dispute which began last year canada reserved its rights as a third-party to the dispute according to trade sources

a trend towards increasing economic and political decentralisation could drive india 's second stage of radical reform britain 's economist magazine said on friday a special report on india will appear in the february 22 issue of the magazine an advance copy of which was given to reuters it said prime minister h.d deve gowda 's ruling coalition is too fragile to successfully meet the challenges that must be surmounted to avoid falling behind other developing nations it called for the pace of economic reforms which began pulling down the decades-old walls of a socialist economy in 1991 to be accelerated `` though india is changing faster than at any time since british rule came to an end the government must accelerate the pace of reform to avoid falling further behind other developing nations especially the east asian tigers '' it said reforms have pushed the country 's growth rate from four percent a year between 1960 and 1990 to roughly seven percent a year since 1994 the magazine said in a statement that accompanied the report `` india 's reformers still have a great deal to do before the task begun in 1991 is complete '' it warned the survey found many public sector enterprises as well as private sector businesses still remain protected against competition though india 's markets have opened to competition though india has reduced its weighted average import tariff to 27 percent from the 1991 level of 87 percent the figure is still twice as high as the average in most of east asia and latin america the economist said in foreign direct investment fdi it said india appears at first glance to be making great progress india received nearly 2 billion of fdi in 1995 -- a handsome increase over 1991 's 150 million but only a fraction of the 38 billion fdi china received in 1995 `` the reason for this as foreign investors unanimously complain is that the system simply does not work as it is supposed to '' the economist said `` india 's future depends on radical reform strong political leadership and a willingness by government to confine its role in the economy to those few crucial areas where free enterprise alone is not enough '' the magazine said `` however the ruling coalition -- an ill-matched grouping of 13 different parties is too fragile to meet these challenges '' but the survey discerned signs that decentralisation could ultimately drive india 's second stage of radical reform `` if states gain more control of their own economic destinies reform-minded state governments could become pioneers of liberalisation promoting competition between states that would in turn promote further reform '' the economist concluded -- bombay newsroom +91-22-265 9000

the focus on tax legislation shifts to the senate next week where a key republican plans to unveil his version of how to cut taxes by a net 85 billion over 5 years the house ways and means committee friday approved a tax cut bill that will ultimately have to be reconciled with the senate version senate finance committee chairman william roth a delaware republican was scheduled to unveil his plan tuesday of how to implement the tax portion of the balanced budget agreement reached between congressional leaders and the white house white house unhappiness with the bill passed by the house committee will also have to be dealt with at some point house speaker newt gingrich said republicans will have to negotiate with president clinton to get a tax bill he will sign but that did not mean they would accept a major rewrite `` we will sit down with the president 's folks and with the president and try to reach an accomodation on issues of great importance to the president '' gingrich said but the georgia republican said that as long as the bill conformed to the overall budget agreement made with clinton `` i do n't think we have an obligation '' to let the white house rewrite it the white house has already begun mounting a campaign for changes in the congressional tax legislation white house spokesman mike mccurry said clinton found several aspects of the legislation `` quite objectionable '' `` the ways and means bill included despite the protests of the president ... some of those very features he considers quite objectionable this is not the bill that 's going to be signed into law '' mccurry said an outline of proposals that roth is considering putting into his legislation showed similarity with the house bill on education tax initiatives that the white house is raising objections about the outline showed the senate finance committee proposal for clinton 's hope scholarship tax credit would like the house bill be a 50 percent tax credit for up to 3,000 of college tuition expenses clinton 's proposal would have made it a straight 1,500 tuition tax credit for higher education administration officials have said the congressional legislation would penalize students attending less-expensive schools like community colleges who might not get the full 1,500 the education tax initiatives in the broad senate finance committee outline were given a preliminary cost estimate of 30 billion over five years the white house has already raised a ruckus over the fact that in the house legislation education tax initiatives were below the 35 billion over five years that clinton sought the balanced budget agreement had said `` roughly '' 35 billion should be included for education tax initiatives the senate finance committee outline also included a capital gains tax cut to 20 percent from the current maximum of 28 percent for individuals the same as in house legislation it did not have anything for a corporate capital gains tax cut the house bill would gradually cut the corporate capital gains tax rate to 30 percent from the current 35 percent the senate finance outline included expanding individual retirement accounts ira which has been a priority for roth it had a proposed 500 per child tax credit that would cost an estimated 83 billion over five years that would be a higher cost than the 71 billion in the house ways and means committee bill the child credit would be allowed for children under age 17 and parents with children aged 13-16 would be required to deposit the credit into an education ira a proposal in both bills for estate tax relief would phase in a higher threshold where the inheritance tax kicks in to 1 million from the current 600,000 gingrich said he expected the measure from the house ways and means committee would pass the house

finance minister theo waigel following the weekend meeting of european finance ministers in dublin said he sees no insurmountable problems clarifying details of the proposed erm ii or the stability pact he added that britain 's participation in european economic and monetary union emu would be desirable `` i see no more insurmountable problems '' waigel said in response to a question at a political party meeting details of the stability pact that remain to be worked out include how sanctions will be imposed for those countries that do not continue to fulfil the convergence criteria after the start of emu he said participants must also narrow the definitions of terms such as `` exceptional '' and `` temporary '' defining the precise circumstances that would allow a country to acceptably exceed the criteria he said waigel initially proposed the concept of a stability pact as a means of ensuring that countries which pass the economic test set for entry to the single currency do not later become lax in their fiscal policies over the weekend officials said a german proposal calling for a deposit of 0.25 percent of gdp for each percentage point of excess deficit was still on the table alongside a european commission proposal for a smaller deposit per percentage point capped at a maximum of 0.5 percent on britain 's participation in emu waigel said `` i hope that the currency union includes as many stability countries as possible and the united kingdom is one of these stability countries '' the financial world is greatly interested that britain not exclude itself from european integration and emu he said -- bonn newsroom 49 228 26097150

inter-american development bank iadb head enrique iglesias friday declared support for government plans to impose austerity measures to cut the country 's bduget deficit `` ecuador has some problems with the budget deficit which the government has to face up to i think that it is taking the necessary measures and in the next few weeks there will be announcements '' iglesias told reporters in quito where he is assessing the country 's economy iglesias said that government officials had informed him of some measures to cut the deficit which are due to be announced monday but declined to say what they were `` i think that ecuador has a chance of significant improvement in the future '' he said he said that the iadb does not make policy recommendations to governments the 1.3 billion deficit is equivalent to 6.6 percent of ecuador 's gross domestic product the government has refused to reveal details of monday 's austerity announcements but official sources told reuters that increases in the prices of fuels and domestic gas are being studied -- gustavo oviedo quito newsroom +5932 25-8433

the city of moscow is planning to issue a eurobond with a three-year maturity rather than a longer one because the bond is a debut issue not because of any restrictions from the central bank a spokesman for the city government said on wednesday `` last summer when we started thinking about our eurobond we decided it should be short as it is our first '' mikhail chernyshov told reuters moscow will issue a 400 million three-year eurobond this summer some western bankers said the central bank had restricted regional eurobond maturities to three years by issuing a foreign exchange licence for only three years a central bank official said the bank the finance ministry and the federal commission on the securities markets were working on a package of regulation for regional eurobond issues he said the three-year term of the licence may be changed but gave no more details russia does not yet have a proper legislation on regional eurobond issues president boris yeltsin had to approve issues by the city of moscow st petersburg and nizhny novgorod -- julie tolkacheva moscow newsroom +7095 941 8520

by paul stewart chief economist at anz banking group nz ltd wellington sept 13 i am sure central bankers would like to think that the process of controlling inflation involves much more science than art but the reality is that policy makers rely upon personal judgement gut feel and a bit of luck more than they would ideally like nonetheless considerable effort does go into developing an objective framework which determines what monetary policy settings are appropriate at any point in time a recent issue of the economist contained an article about one such attempt the rule developed in 1993 by john taylor an economist at stanford university taylor currently an adviser to bob dole argued that central banks should `` lean against the wind '' when setting interest rates and provide a method to calculate the appropriate level of short term interest rates given the prevailing inflation and growth conditions the economist noted that both taylor 's work and subsequent research suggested that the central banks in the u.s. germany and japan have whether by accident or design effectively been following the rule for some time so what about new zealand taylor 's rule says that short term interest rates say 90 day bank bills should be equal to the real short term interest rate i.e actual interest rate less inflation which is consistent with `` neutral '' monetary policy plus the expected inflation rate plus minus 0.5 percent for every percent that current inflation is above below its target plus minus 0.5 percent for every percent that current gdp growth is above below the potential gdp growth rate as a starting point for new zealand we adopted five percent as the neutral real short term interest rate three percent as the potential growth rate and the rbnz 's underlying inflation forecast 12 months forward as the expected inflation rate on that basis what does taylor 's rule tell us about monetary policy in the 1990s firstly it suggests that in the late 1993/early 1994 monetary policy was too loose in retrospect most would agree that to be a fair assessment because with the economy strengthening the rbnz 's inflation forecasts at that point were overly optimistic secondly it suggests that monetary policy is currently overly restrictive according to the rule short term interest rates should be around 2.5-3.0 percent lower than they are at present however thirdly it suggests that apart from the brief period in 1993-94 monetary policy has been too tight for all of the last six years and that is where the rule or our application of it starts to go wrong if monetary policy has been consistently too tight then clearly underlying inflation should have been less than one percent the mid-point of the target possibly even below zero percent for most of that period the fact that underlying inflation has never been below one percent and has spent a considerable amount of time near the top of or above the inflation target implies that monetary policy has if anything been too loose so what is wrong with the rule and why does n't it apply to new zealand an important issue is that taylor 's rule focuses exclusively upon interest rates that may be reasonably appropriate for the u.s. but in a small trade-dependent economy where the exposure to imported inflation is much higher a measure which does not explicitly capture the impact of the exchange rate on monetary conditions will be incomplete another possibility is that we have applied the rule incorrectly specifically we have rather subjectively set the `` neutral '' real short term interest rate at five percent we could use the average historical short term rate for the u.s. and u.k. that is around two percent and 3.5 percent respectively indeed applying new zealand 's average for the last six years around 6.5 percent does improve the fit of the rule to actual rates however in another research paper cited by the economist alison stuart of the bank of england notes that `` theoretically '' the neutral real short term rate should be close to the long run trend rate of economic growth that would imply a much lower rate for new zealand 3.0-3.5 percent which would then reduce the performance of the taylor rule further taylor 's rule seems to add little in the new zealand context and i would argue has limited use for any economy the fact is that the process of controlling inflation and setting monetary policy is not a simple mechanical process based on exact information economic relationships are complex and contingent upon the human factor changeable through time the difficulty faced by central bankers in rigorously analysing large amounts of sketchy and often lagged information as a basis for setting policy which will have an imprecise impact upwards of a year into the future should not be underestimated however this exercise has reinforced one important point that is real short term interest rates in new zealand have remained persistently high compared to other industrialised economies why is that essentially despite modest inflation expectations generally measured at 2.0-3.0 percent household and business behaviour is not yet consistent with a low inflation environment new zealanders appear to have a very high propensity to borrow especially for property investment and are reluctant to save even with high real interest rates until that changes the reserve bank will have to `` lean a little more heavily against the wind '' than the taylor rule advocates note the opinions expressed in this article represent the views of the author only they should not be seen as reflecting the views of reuters

french unemployment leapt to a record in august with the biggest monthly increase in more than three years pushing the jobless rate to 12.6 percent at a time when government economic policy is under increasing fire the number of people out of work in france jumped 39,500 in august to 3,085,100 and the jobless rate based on international labour organisation ilo criteria which exclude jobseekers who did any work hit a record 12.6 percent up from 12.5 percent `` it 's an extraordinary number quite a shock '' said philippe brossard an economist with abn amro investment bank in paris the leap in jobless numbers will turn up the heat on prime minister alain juppe whose policy of austerity and spending cuts is coming under increasing criticism from the ranks of his own centre-right ruling coalition as well as trade unions `` this is going to raise the gloom and unhappiness in the parliament we 're heading for a tough political weekend '' said brossard juppe has called a parliamentary confidence vote for next wednesday in an effort to unite his fractious coalition sniping from within his own rpr party prompted president jacques chirac to intervene in juppe 's defence on thursday juppe has been counting on an upturn in the economy in the second half of this year and had got a fillip from news earlier this week that household spending was gathering pace but the latest jobless figures will do nothing to help his efforts to talk up public morale as juppe and chirac fight to dispel gloom and crank up consumer spending and business investment brossard and several other specialists said the latest news reinforced the view that there would have to be further interest rate cutting by the bank of france to help the economy economists said it was still hard to measure the social and political fall-out `` clearly it 's important because it comes amid tensions in the government but as long as chirac supports juppe we should not have too much of a political fight '' said david naude an economist with jp morgan bank despite already simmering labour union tension naude said the surge in unemployment could actually have the effect of cowing people rather than sparking unrest `` when people see jobless numbers rising they may be less willing to demand pay rises or strike '' he said `` it 's not clear-cut '' valerie plagnol an economist at credit commercial de france said `` it does increase the potential for social tensions when there is little hope for unemployment and these are only august numbers there were plans to cut more jobs in a number of sectors in september '' `` it also means that pickup in household consumption in third quarter wo n't be supportive for the fourth quarter economic growth the momentum beyond third quarter can not be assured at all '' she said french unemployment had fallen by 20,000 in july but that drop had been written off by economists as an aberration due to seasonal factors `` the figures are the reflection of an economy that remains weak i would expect unemployment to keep edging up to reach around 12.7 12.8 percent by the end of the year '' jean-louis mourier economist at louis dreyfus finance said in the wake of the august data

yugoslavia hopes to soon set up free trade regimes with bosnia and croatia just as it did with macedonia last month making the first steps towards a regional customs union the daily nasa borba said on thursday `` on yugoslavia 's part there are no obstacles for such cooperation to be renewed as soon as possible '' yugoslav prime minister radoje kontic was quoted by the paper as saying kontic referred to cooperation with `` old partners in bosnia-herzegovina not only in the bosnian serb republic but also in the moslem-croat federation '' kontic said the creation of a free trade zone with macedonia had opened prospects for reviving full cooperation and that he expected certain free trade regimes `` comparatively soon '' with croatia as well `` the establishing of economic cooperation on the territory of former yugoslavia is inevitable '' kontic said yugoslavia and macedonia abolished trade tariffs on most goods produced in the two countries exempt are strategic yugoslav agricultural products and livestock and certain macedonian ferrous metallurgy products cigarettes buses and refrigerators which remain on quotas some independent analysts earlier this month described the move as the first step towards a regional trade union but milojko arsic of the centre for economic studies cesmekon said an ex-yugoslav regional free trade zone was too narrow and would not contribute greatly to economic recovery `` although it could be stimulative to raising production it would not be a generator of economic growth since we will probably never achieve the volume of trade we had before the breakup of former yugoslavia '' arsic told reuters -- amra kevic belgrade newsroom +381 11 2224305

china looks set to replace japan as the biggest source of u.s. trade deficits and commercial frictions that washington may find far more difficult to resolve trade analysts say the commerce department reported this week that for the first time the u.s. trade deficit with china in june surpassed the shortfall with japan economists said they expect china to top the monthly list periodically in the future as the u.s. shortfall with japan shrinks and the imbalance with china grows `` in the long term china is going to be our no 1 problem '' said norwest corp. chief economist sung won sohn `` and the problem with china is that they operate by a completely different set of rules the concept of a free and open market is alien to them '' u.s. secretary of commerce mickey kantor blamed the shortfall on closed markets and chinese trade policies that maximize exports while limiting imports kantor said he did not expect to see a deficit this year with china much higher than the 34 billion shortfall last year but that the administration was not happy with the trend `` because of discrimination against u.s. goods in the chinese market we need to make more progress '' he said `` we need to make our trade agreements work '' the united states and china moved to the brink of a trade war earlier this year over what washington said was beijing 's failure to enforce a 1995 agreement to protect copyrights and other intellectual property from rampant piracy the dispute was resolved when china promised to beef up enforcement trade analysts say they expect to see more such disputes with china as washington presses beijing to open markets to more u.s. good and even out the balance of trade the united states they said has some leverage in those disputes because it represents china 's largest market but they also argue that beijing 's leverage is growing as the united states becomes more dependent on china as an inexpensive source of a growing variety of consumer goods including textiles shoes toys and electronics in the long run analysts said it is in the interest of the united states for china to join the world trade organization wto beijing wants to join the global trade system as a developing nation that would enjoy more lenient rules washington noting the huge size of the chinese economy has objected and insisted china join the world body on more commercially acceptable terms analysts said it is also in the long-term interest of china to join the global trading body if it wants to continue to attract foriegn investment and be assured of continued access to u.s. markets `` in order for china to attract foreign investment at the levels it must in order to continue to grow and deal with the demands of a huge populace it has to be a full member of the global trading system '' said david rothkopf a former commerce department official but kenneth dewoskin a china expert at the university of michigan said the chinese may have lost interest -- at least for now -- in joining the global trading forum because of the cost in terms of economic reforms that would be required in order to become a member and because they no longer fear losing u.s most favored nation status during this year 's debate on china 's mfn a number of key lawmakers made clear they would like to end the annual ritual and make the status permanent next year the mfn status allows chinese goods to enter the country at the same low tariffs granted most other trading nations `` the big benefit of joining the wto is access to the north american market -- and they have that -- and slighly improved access to europe and japan '' dewoskin said `` but the cost is very high ''

the polish senate 's decision to cut personal income tax levels next year by one point reduces uncertainty over the probable 1997 budget deficit now likely to be near this year 's 2.8 percent of gross domestic product gdp the senate on thursday amended the lower house 's income tax bill and introduced levels at 20 32 and 44 percent in 1997 slightly higher than those proposed by the government and defeated in the lower house late last month deputy finance minister waldemar manugiewicz told reuters that if the senate decision came into force the government would amend its current budget draft to accommodate lower tax revenues and a higher deficit of about 2.8 percent of gdp `` if the senate 's decision becomes law then obviously the deficit will increase by about 850-900 million zlotys to 2.8 percent of gdp from 2.6 percent assumed by the current draft '' manugiewicz said he said budget expenditures would remain unchanged and the higher deficit would be financed by increased revenues from privatisation of banks and sales of government paper abroad he also said some of the cash left in consumers pockets due to lower taxes would return to the treasury 's coffers as indirect taxes such as value added tax vat and excise tax the senate amendments now return to the lower house which can either adopt them or uphold its proposal for a four-level tax scale granting sharp tax cuts for people on low incomes which the government has deemed economically unsound if the lower house were to reaffirm this four-level scale president aleksander kwasniewski linked to the ruling coalition 's larger party the democratic left alliance sld has suggested he would veto the bill his veto would in effect keep the present 21- 33- and 45-percent tax levels intact and the 1997 budget unchanged from the government draft now being debated in parliament which assumes no tax cuts and a deficit of 2.6 percent of gdp but the senate amendments appear set to survive the lower house vote after the main opposition party the union for freedom indicated it would support them along with the sld `` i confirm that the union for freedom will vote in favour of this scale '' party chairman leszek balcerowicz said last month uw deputies joined other opposition members and the co-ruling polish peasant party psl to push through the four-level tax scale a move that stunned the government with the uw the sld which backed the one-point tax reduction can muster more than the 50 percent of votes in the lower house needed to uphold the senate decision finance minister grzegorz kolodko welcomed the senate vote saying the amended bill fit in broadly with government plans -- warsaw newsroom +48 22 653 9700

proposals to bail out countries pushed by almost unpayable debts into deepening poverty are so rigid that very few stand much hope of help before the turn of the century the commonwealth said in a confidential report obtained by reuters on tuesday and on the top of the agenda at this week 's meeting of commonwealth finance ministers in this caribbean island the group argues that the international community have imposed too many rules `` these restrictions reduce to only 11 the number of countries likely to receive multilateral debt relief and delay relief so that only three will receive comprehensive treatment '' it said several of the 53 members of the commonwealth which groups memebrs of the former british empire are saddled with large debts to multilateral financial institutions such as the international monetary fund imf and world bank historically the poorer countries have been forced to borrow from these institutions whose industrial nation shareholders only recently agreed to even consider writing off some of the debt by contrast major developing countries such as in latin america were able to borrow from commercial banks with whom they subsequently rescheduled defaulted debt payments into far easier terms britain has been pressing for greater help including selling some of the imf 's 40 billion in gold reserves to release funds for the heavily indebted poor countries the issue will be one of the main topics at next week 's annual imf/world bank meeting in washington when industrial countries will come under further pressure to do more to help the poor `` in theory up to 20 countries are eligible for debt relief but in reality they are focusing on only two or three '' one commonwealth official said `` the proposals currently being developed need considerable strengthening if they are to have a decisive impact on the multilateral debt problems of heavily indebted poor countries '' the report said adding that it welcomed steps taken thus far the report which commonwealth sources said had input from the british treasury said the criteria and time-frame for countries to join in any relief scheme were too restrictive for example a country has to have a proven three-year economic track record before individual creditor countries will help and another three after that before the multilateral financial agencies step in the question of the imf selling some of its gold has yet to be resolved after two years of debate with countries such as germany fiercely opposed to selling what they see as the imf 's family jewels last week the imf 's board put off any decision on the sale of gold until consensus could be reached financing the relief is also open to doubt the report said that the imf and world bank estimate the cost of the initiative would be 5.6 billion of which they will only provide 2 billion it urged that the criteria be changed so that as many countries as possible get relief by 2000 and that it is funded fairly among all the creditors and not shouldered by budget- conscious industrial countries -- bermuda newsroom +1 441 238-8000 reuter jwt

the german bundesbank will have no grounds to raise interest rates any time soon and may even have scope to lower credit costs further this economic cycle a member of the bank 's policy-making council said on tuesday olaf sievert president of the regional central bank based in the east german city of leipzig also said in a speech he believed worries that currency markets could be very turbulent in the run-up to european monetary union were exaggerated speaking at a reception in leipzig sievert said `` i see nothing which could give us grounds to take a firmer grip on the monetary reins '' he added that it was hard to say whether there could be scope for further cuts in leading interest rates this cycle the bundesbank has held its lombard and discount rates steady since april but it reduced a key money market rate in august `` whether there is room to manoeuvre on the downside remains to be seen '' he said according to the text of his speech which was released in advance sievert said the outlook for german inflation continued to be favourable despite increases in raw materials prices `` the prospects for the future also look good '' he said noting annual german inflation is now running at around 1.4 percent this fact together with expectations that money supply growth will slow in 1997 meant that the bundesbank did not have to be too concerned about the fact that m3 money supply growth overshot the central bank 's target in 1996 he said `` the overshooting of the goal is no reason for considerable concern given that the pace of money supply growth had already started to slow last spring '' he said good news for the economy lay in the fact that the excessive appreciation in the mark seen in 1995 when the dollar tumbled to an all-time low had corrected `` the appreciation of the mark seen in spring 1995 which was absolutely unfitting for the real economy has in the meantime been corrected '' sievert said the likelihood of further currency market turbulence ahead of the planned creation of the euro in 1999 also seemed smaller than many feared he said adding that he did not expect this to be a major problem over the next two years looking ahead to possible problems sievert said `` i am not thinking here so much of the widespread fear that speculative trends on financial markets could create turbulence which will make the task of monetary policy more difficult '' `` there are possibbly exaggerated worries here '' he added growing consensus in financial markets that european monetary union emu would start on time in 1999 meant that any speculation was more likely to be `` stabilising speculation and not destabilising speculation '' `` that is in any case true for the internal relationship between the currency areas which will form a single currency area from the start of monetary union '' sievert added he added that it would be more difficult to ensure stable relationships between currencies which entered emu and those initially left outside countries which wish to merge their currencies in the euro from 1999 onward must meet goals on public deficits public debt interest rates exchange rates and inflation this year in his text sievert also dismissed a french proposal to create a `` stability council '' as a political counterweight to the future european central bank this proposal appeared to be a meaningless attempt to find some form of mediator for monetary policy which had the clearly defined role of price stability as its absolute priority noting that the council in contrast to the ecb itself would have no real decision-making power he added `` but why then bother with such a council at all '' -- frankfurt newsroom +49 69 756525

argentina collected 236 million in income tax and 105 million in personal wealth levies in 1996 national tax service dgi head carlos silvani said tuesday silvani told reporters that the figures could not be compared with 1995 data because this year individuals who have a partnership in a company are only due to pay their income and personal wealth tax by may `` making a comparison is very difficult '' he said last week was the deadline for collection of the two annual taxes despite the change in the deadline for individuals who have a partnership in a company making comparisons difficult silvani said he was optimistic tax collection was going well `` i think we have enough facts to say that things are going well '' he told reporters he anticipated another 100,000 income tax statements and at least 15 percent more personal wealth statements will have been submitted by the time the may deadline runs out -- axel bugge buenos aires newsroom +541 318-0668

trade ministers scrambled on wednesday to reach an accord aimed at cutting tariffs on information technology while struggling to reconcile deep-seated differences over workers rights negotiators from the united states and the european union scheduled another round of meetings on the sidelines of a 128-nation trade conference in singapore to settle their remaining disagreements over the outline of an information technology agreement ita after meeting in four closed-door sessions on tuesday `` there is not an agreement yet '' european union trade commissioner sir leon brittan said on wednesday after meeting acting u.s. trade representative charlene barshefsky `` there is agreement on many points there are some outstanding ones we are trying to resolve those '' brittan said the united states with strong backing from japan is keen to see an accord to free up trade in the 600 billion market for computers software chips and other high-technology products by the year 2000 before the end of this week 's first ministerial meeting of the world trade organisation wto `` there is no question that what the industrialised countries now hope for most here is a deal on information technology products and agreement to work hard for a basic telecommunications pact by february '' said one key negotiator the big four trade powers -- the united states the eu japan and canada -- hope to settle their differences in particular over the touchy question of product coverage before meeting again later on wednesday with other nations interested in joining the infotech accord `` they the big four are still fighting some working-level negotiators of some countries are getting crazy '' a japanese givernment source told reuters `` i am hopeful we will reach a consensus before the afternoon meeting starts '' developing countries were shown a draft outline late on tuesday of an accord worked out by the big four but the draft did not specify product coverage or spell out what sort of flexibility could be shown to developing countries on the timing of the tariff cuts the japanese source said progress on the infotech deal looked less elusive than on the contentious issue of whether the 128-nation wto set up in 1995 as the successor to the general agreement on tariffs and trade should get involved in enforcing labour standards the united states with strong backing from france and norway says that without action to tackle the exploitation of child labour and eradicate sweatshop conditions in the third world support for free trade in rich countries will evaporate diplomats said that washington digging in its heels had repeated a threat to reject other parts of the meeting 's final declaration to be published on friday unless it won mention of the labour issue poorer countries are equally adamant in rejecting a scrutiny role for the wto they say attempts to impose workplace rules is protectionism in disguise because the trade advantages their cheap labour gives them would be whittled away on wednesday malaysia again rejected the attempts to put labour rights on the official wto agenda `` the debate on the issue of labour standards has indeed proven to be a divisive factor rafidah aziz malaysia 's international trade and industry minister said in a speech `` we reject any move to discuss and deliberate labour standards and other social clauses in the wto '' rafidah said bill jordon secretary-general of the international confederation of free trade unions icftu told a news conference he was hopeful some compromise could be reached but said it might take the form of a statement asking the wto director-general to take up the issue with his counterpart at the international labour organisation ilo `` i am hopeful that the two extremes of this argument can find a place within one statement '' jordan said `` i did not expect the wto to take on board all that we want ... what we want them to do is to recognise their responsibility in the process of the globalisation of trade '' delegates have meanwhile been edging towards consensus on textiles and agriculture as well as over how the world trade body should tackle government procurement investment rules and domestic competition policy

reserve bank of new zealand rbnz governor don brash said on tuesday he would like a new mix of lower foreign exchange rates and higher interest rates to take the economy forward since january 1993 the currency has risen more than 40 percent against the u.s. dollar advancing from us 0.5010 to as high as us 0.7170 in november 1996 `` i 'd be much happier with a somewhat lower exchange rate and somewhat higher interest rates '' said brash in an interview with reuters financial television rftv `` we 've had a very strong rise in exchange rates and a fall in interest rates now i 'd prefer to see a different combination -- somewhat lower exchange rates and somewhat higher interest rates '' brash said new zealand 's strong currency has hit exporters particularly hard and put pressure on the new centre-right national-new zealand first coalition to curb spending plans the rbnz does not set interest rates administratively like most central banks of industrialised countries but relies on regulating the amount of cash in the system brash added `` we can be happy with a lower currency if we have higher interest rates and vice versa '' asked to give an optimum level for the new zealand dollar he said `` the best level for the currency is the level which delivers ongoing price stability at this point we look as though this will be achieved '' the new zealand dollar was trading at us 0.6970 by 1304 gmt compared with us 0.6950 at the wellington close on tuesday brash repeated the central bank 's view inflation would fall below 1.0 percent next year then rise through 1999 to 2000 `` the biggest single factor in the second half of this year particularly is the delayed response of new zealand prices to the rise in the exchange rate which we 've seen over the last two or three years '' he said although the inflation target band was increased last year to zero-to-3.0 percent from zero-to-2.0 percent brash said `` i 'd be very disappointed indeed if we went above 3.0 percent '' if inflation did go above the 3.0 percent target he said he would reconsider his position as governor `` whenever we go outside the target over the top or under the bottom i look very carefully at my position and so does the board '' he said in terms of gross domestic product data brash said he was as surprised as many analysts were by the strength of the december quarter when the economy grew 0.7 percent `` we were expecting gdp in the march 97 quarter to be up by only some 2.0 percent over the march 96 quarter and in fact it looks at this stage as though it might be slightly stronger '' he said -- international bonds unit +44 171 542 6137

thailand 's new government on wednesday detailed major policy initiatives to tackle the slowing national economy but economic analysts said the proposals were vague prime minister chavalit yongchaiyudh who took office earlier this month vowed in a speech to parliamnent to uphold fiscal discipline reduce spending deregulate the financial sector and stimulate the slowing economy chavalit 's heads a six-party coalition government that replaced the administration of previous premier banharn silpa-archa banharn was accused of economic mismanagement analysts said the government had identified key economic woes afflicting the nation but had left markets and investors hungry for details on strategies and implementation `` anyone can present policy like that it 's too vague at least there should be more details to assure us that the policy will be implemented in the right direction '' said arporn chewakriengkrai chief economist at deutsche morgan grenfell `` on fiscal discipline for example the government should have at least spelt out that it will not allow fiscal deficits instead of just saying it will uphold fiscal discipline '' she said arporn also said the government had failed to spell out its policies on the direction it wants interest rates to take and on the future of the baht and the system under which it is fixed daily the government pledged that it would curb the current account gap which the central bank expects to rise up to 8.3 percent of gross domestic product gdp this year by boosting savings and foreign exchange earnings and reducing spending thailand 's exports the country 's growth engine during the past decade recorded the slowest growth in years in 1996 growing just 0.9 percent in the first nine months against 20 percent during the same period last year the government also vowed to develop thai money and capital markets to boost regional competitiveness and to deregulate the financial sector maintain price stability and revive the depressed property sector thailand 's stock market is now at a three-year low as many foreign investors have left to invest elsewhere in the region following a year of political uncertainty `` the overall picture looked fine the government seemed to address the problems we are facing but it should give us some hints on its measures and action plans '' said somjai phagaphasvivat a professor at thammsart university somjai said wednesday 's announcement painted some contradictory pictures `` the government needed to tell us how to curb the current account deficit while at the same time seeking to expand various capital-intensive infrastructure projects '' he said

tokyo stocks are unlikely to fall drastically and the japanese government wants the prices to move in a stable manner chief cabinet secretary seiroku kajiyama told a news conference on tuesday `` stocks remained soft but i have a feeling the price decline will not be very drastic ... i want a stable attitude in the market '' kajiyama said tokyo stocks struggled back up above the 20,000 level by midday tuesday after dipping below that key level earlier the first time the nikkei has been below 20,000 since march 15 brokers said at midday the benchmark nikkei 225 average was up 88.73 points or 0.44 percent to 20,195.84 off a low of 19,920.02 its september futures were up 60 points to 20,210

the european union will seek to become more competitive with the united states and canada in trade with mexico during free-trade negotiations with mexico next month the european union 's ambassador to mexico said in an interview `` right now we 're not in a good position to compete '' mexico 's jacques lecomte told reuters `` there 's the problem of duties that of the distance and the value of the u.s. dollar compared with the european currencies '' lecomte said mexico and the eu likely would start negotiations in the second half of october in a bid to free trade barriers small and medium-sized exporters stand to gain the most from such a deal `` the big businesses do n't need help '' lecomte said `` if they have problems with tariffs they can negotiate bilaterally trilaterally or globally it 's not that way for a small company '' mexican exports to the european union grew 20 percent in 1995 over 1994 to 3.38 billion according to mexican government statistics at the same time mexico imported 6.72 billion worth of goods from the european union the united states remained the most important trading partner for both mexico and the european union doing more than 120 billion in trade with mexico alone lecomte said an important part of the trade between mexico and the united states involves european comapanies he cited the example of german car-maker volkswagen ag which sells many of its mexican-made cars in the united states the mexican-european talks also will include the topic of battling drug traffickers lecomte said `` it 's a key element in economic and trade relations '' lecomte said -- mara luisa aguilar mexico city newsroom 525 728-9553

proposed changes in venezuela 's social security system got a lukewarm reception from business leaders on friday when union leaders formally presented their reform plans to the tripartite commission the commission gathers private sector leaders union and government officials in an attempt to break a long-standing impasse over social security reform -- seen as a prerequisite for a long awaited restructuring of the 1.2 million strong venezuelan public sector `` there are some matters in their proposal that worry us '' leading business chamber fedecamaras president jorge serrano told reporters under current rules fired workers are paid twice their monthly salary for each year worked while retiring workers are paid once government and private sector leaders say such a scheme prevents increases in worker salaries take home pay is boosted instead when needed with monthly bonds under changes proposed by venezuela 's largest union the confederation of venezuelan workers ctv workers would be paid severance payments according to a sliding scale workers on salaries less than 53,000 bolivars a month would receive three months salary for each year worked while those with salaries over 500,000 bolivars would receive one month 's pay ctv president federico ramirez leon said the scale favored those who are paid less `` which are most is this country '' but serrano said he favored moving towards a new system of social security payments rather than a tinkering of the current method -- oscar galvis caracas newsroom 582 505 2600

the probability spain will be in european monetary and economic union emu from the start is now close to 100 percent according to a spanish banker `` the probability spain will be in the first wave of countries taking part in europe 's single currency is now close to 100 percent '' said pedro luis uriarte managing director of banco bilbao vizcaya bbv at a seminar `` it 's even higher than the probability of some core countries '' uriarte said he added that both the government and the bank of spain were `` working hard '' toward such an achievement -- madrid newsroom 341 585 8340

france 's economy needs shock treatment to boost sluggish growth cut unemployment and combat inequality socialist leader lionel jospin said on tuesday outlining his party 's economic programme for a march 1998 general election jospin said the socialists would provide the required jolt if they won `` we need to create a shock with a new policy of growth which is why i believe in the need for an original policy that strongly attacks unemployment and inequality and seizes france 's problems while building a europe that is both ambitious and attainable '' jospin told a news conference conservative prime minister alain juppe retorted in parliament that the socialist platform would `` lead france back into the spiral of decline '' france is suffering from record 12.7 percent unemployment and slow growth and the population is deeply sceptical of prospects for a lasting economic rebound the pressure to lower deficits to qualify for a single european currency is an extra constraint that would not relent under a different government to counter the problems jospin offered a plan to reduce the work week to 35 hours without cutting pay create 700,000 jobs -- mostly for the young -- and reform health insurance payments he said his policies offered a clear alternative to those of the centre-right government which he accused of focusing on electoral inducements at the expense of fundamental reform he contrasted his detailed policy statement with what he called the woolly `` communications events '' staged recently by president jacques chirac and juppe but his proposals while more reliant on state action were strikingly similar to some government policies in the last 18 months if they won the election which opinion polls suggest is unlikely the socialists hands would be tied by many of the same constraints hobbling juppe 's government though the ruling coalition still leads in most polls the socialists and their left-wing allies have edged to within striking distance a february 18 poll by bva for weekly paris match found that the left would win 31.5 percent of the vote an increase of two percentage points from a month earlier compared to 36.5 percent for the majority a decline of less than one point juppe 's government has removed some of the burden of funding the welfare state from payroll charges launched youth employment initiatives and enabled companies to reduce the work week all without making a dent in the jobless rate jospin charged that chirac was locked into backward-looking policies that kept the economy from achieving its growth potential which he put at three percent a year in 1996 the economy grew 1.3 percent and the government has said it expects growth of at least 2.3 percent this year `` a new situation demands new policies our problem is no longer inflation which has been beaten nor our trade balance which is in surplus our problem is mass unemployment '' he said while saying the primary solution to france 's jobs crisis lay in stronger private sector growth jospin pledged to create 350,000 public sector jobs in two years by creating a new long-term work contract he said this five-year contract would gradually replace existing shorter-term youth employment schemes it would be paid for by shifting money from existing initiatives as for the 350,000 private sector jobs he envisioned jospin said he would rely on a `` moral obligation '' among employers many of these jobs could be freed up by offering retirement to employees with 40 years service he said this measure would cost about eight billion francs a year for five years

u.s. treasury secretary robert rubin urged japan friday to guard against a resurgence in its trade surplus but rejected suggestions that a stronger japanese currency was the best way to do that rubin told the american chamber of commerce here that japan needed to promote strong domestic demand for its products open its markets further to imports and deregulate its economy `` it is critical that japan 's current account surplus not rise again to a level that is detrimental to global growth that causes trade friction with japan 's trading partners and that could fuel protectionist sentiments '' he told the business leaders after meeting prime minister ryutaro hashimoto japan 's trade surplus rose in february for the first time in two years as the weak yen helped make the nation 's exports more competitive in world markets speaking to reporters on his way here rubin made clear that he did not see a stronger yen -- and by inference a weaker dollar -- as the best way to contain and cut japan 's surplus `` we do n't believe in anybody using their currency for trade policies -- us or anybody else '' he said u.s. business leaders however made clear to rubin that they were concerned about the weakness of the yen -- which has fallen about 50 percent against the dollar over the past two years boosting japanese competitiveness in the process `` at current exchange rates our profitability here is being killed '' robert orr director of government relations for nippon motorola ltd told rubin rubin has consistently maintained that a strong dollar is in america 's interests -- a stance he alluded to on friday -- because it keeps down u.s. inflation and interest rates but he has also recently taken to saying that the u.s. currency has been strong for some time in an apparent effort to signal that he is not eager to see a further dollar advance the dollar did rise on friday jumping more than one yen to 123.79 yen in late asian trade as the market took rubin 's remarks to mean he would not actively push for a stronger yen publicly rubin appeared willing to give japan the benefit of the doubt -- for now -- that its policy gamble of mixing fiscal tightening with promised deregulation could achieve growth without relying on an export drive some u.s. officials are worried that a rise in japan 's sales tax that took effect this week will sap demand at home and force japanese companies to seek bigger profits overseas `` i do n't think there is any question ... about his prime minister ryutaro hashimoto 's commitment to deregulation and economic growth in japan it strikes me as a very sound policy path to be on '' rubin told a news conference but rubin reserved judgment as to whether japan 's policy would succeed `` only time will tell '' he said the treasury chief warned that washington and other trade partners had `` enormous interest '' in how japan 's economy fared and whether tokyo would act if its policy gamble failed japanese officials said hashimoto agreed with rubin at their half-hour meeting that domestic demand-led growth was important for japan as it was for the united states hashimoto repeated japanese assurances that tokyo 's surplus was unlikely to grow drastically and that the economic impact from the consumption tax rise would be limited looking back over the past four years rubin said that both the united states and japan had worked hard to iron out trade friction and strengthen their economic relationship he noted that japan 's current account surplus -- the broadest measure of trade -- has fallen from the equivalent of 3.1 percent of gross domestic product in 1993 to 1.4 percent four years ago washington tried unsuccessfully to convince tokyo to adopt a surplus target of 1.5 to 2 percent of gross domestic product but rubin said friday that washington did not have a target for the surplus now his visit to japan follows a series of trips to tokyo by u.s. officials including vice president al gore and deputy treasury secretary lawrence summers but rubin denied there was a concerted u.s. strategy to turn up the heat on japan rubin was to leave tokyo later in the day for a meeting of asia-pacific finance ministers in the philippines

italy received encouraging words from one major economic body on tuesday in its battle to qualify for a single european currency but appeared to get a warning from another key organisation the organisation for economic cooperation and development oecd said heavily indebted italy was `` within reach '' of meeting key goals laid out in the maastricht treaty for founder members of european economic and monetary union emu a report by the paris-based group said prime minister romano prodi faced a daunting task as he tried to halve italy 's budget deficit this year to meet one of the key emu criteria but added `` such a reduction is not unprecedented among oecd economies '' prodi 's centre-left government has introduced a string of tough budget moves over the past 12 months in a bid to wrestle the deficit down to three percent of gross domestic product gdp from 6.7 percent in 1996 the oecd said many of the measures introduced so far had been tax hikes or financial operations and urged the government to embark on structural spending cuts to keep a lid on the deficit in coming years however the annual report of the european monetary institute emi lashed out at one-off measures to reduce deficit to gdp ratios saying they `` can not be regarded as contributing to sustainability '' the forerunner of a european central bank said heavy reliance on higher revenues rather than spending cuts to rein in deficits was `` a ground for concern '' while not mentioning any countries by name many analysts took the remarks to be aimed at italy among others only about one year remains before the european commission reaches a final decision based on 1997 data on which eu states would qualify for emu prodi said in an interview published on monday that he was confident italy would meet the strict maastricht parameters adding that italians knew that joining european monetary union was `` a battle that counts for centuries '' the prime minister told time magazine that if italy failed to join from the start `` i would feel compelled to resign '' aware of unease in the emi and germany over the methods being used to get italy to the starting line for a single currency prodi has pledged to introduce an overhaul of the politically sensitive welfare state before the end of the year while italy 's social spending is slightly less than the eu average analysts say the system is unbalanced with too much money being channelled into generous state pensions as the population ages this represents a budget time bomb `` the government is committed to start examining this over the coming weeks '' treasury minister carlo azeglio ciampi told reporters on tuesday but analysts said the main problem for italy remained the huge servicing costs on its debt mountain `` the crucial point is interest spending '' said andrea conti an analyst with deutsche bank in milan the more the markets believe that italy will lower its deficit the more interest rates will fall and the oecd said italy could expect significant interest savings this year as the country 's economic credibility improved it called on prodi and ciampi to stick to their guns `` the task faced by macroeconomic policies is unusually demanding and with the outcome remaining subject to considerable uncertainty success requires a sustained policy effort to which the government is committed '' the oecd added

seven eastern and central european launched a drive on tuesday to lure more singapore investors into their emerging markets the singapore trade development board tdb which promotes foreign investment in singapore and encourages firms to invest overseas said singaporeans had shown interest in manufacturing trading infrastructure and hospitality services the tdb will lead a trade mission of 15 to 20 singapore firms in may to poland slovenia hungary czech republic bulgaria croatia and latvia the countries involved in a conference staged to launch the investment drive `` we hope to highlight the business opportunities available and increase market transparency of the region '' barry desker tdb 's chief executive officer told the conference singapore 's bilateral trade with eastern and central europe has grown 200 percent since 1990 to singapore 3 billion us 2 billion in 1996 desker said singapore 's total investment commitment in the region has reached over s 500 million mainly in real estate manufacturing and warehousing he said bank austria 's franz horhager told the conference that potential investors should not venture into these markets alone `` you need to be guided into these markets once you 're guided you can circumvent easily the traps pitfalls problems with local currencies and government regulations '' said horhager the bank 's director of international commercial banking and global networking management horhager said he was optimistic about the investment advantages these former communist countries had over asia 's emerging economies like cambodia or burma given their abundantly cheap skilled labour force `` in eastern central europe people are skilled technicians engineers the percentage of academdic degree is extremely high that 's their main thrust '' horhager said businessmen in the audience told reuters they were wary about investing in the region due to a lack of knowledge on the various countries politics financial operations legalities and business climate horhager said such problems had eased in recent years `` things have calmed down since the breakdown of soviet union economic structures are in place with proper legal systems and new constitution problems are no longer characteristic of eastern europe but how they are going to sell their products or get a good price '' horhager said `` most important is the countries legal reliability and that 's the biggest achievements we have witnessed for the region '' he said us 1 s 1.44 -- singapore newsroom 65 8703080

chinese vice premier li lanqing said on wednesday the world trade organisation wto would be ineffective without china as a member `` china needs wto and wto also needs china without china i 'm afraid to say that the world trade organisation can not fully exert its influence '' li told asian and pacific businessmen in manila `` without the mutual recognition of diversity and stress on flexibility and without adherence to the principle of equality ... the development of the asia- pacific and world economy will be unattainable '' he added li said china the fastest growing market in the world was ready to join the world trade body but would not commit to what was beyond its means `` china being a developing country adheres to the principle that rights and obligations should be in balance and can not commit itself to what exceeds its capacity and ability '' li said li however said china would continue to pursue market-oriented reforms initiated by late paramount leader deng xiaoping he said average tariff rates in the country have been scaled down to 23 percent from 35.9 percent and will be subject to further reductions by the year 2000 `` this policy will not be changed and should not be changed ... china is capable of developing its economy in a sustained speedy and healthy manner '' he said wto director-general renato ruggiero said on tuesday that china must present an ambitious programme to open up its markets in its negotiations to join the trade watchdog china and its major trading partners will hold talks in geneva this month on beijing 's bid to join the wto -- manila newsroom 63 2 841-8938 fax 817-6267
