indigenous shamen and tribal elders from across the americas were airlifted on saturday to the far reaches of colombia 's amazon jungle to begin a week-long meeting aimed at rescuing mother earth some 400 native indian representatives headed to the town of araracuara aboard two colombian air force hercules transport planes and were then due to paddle up the river caqueta to hold council in a traditional ceremonial long-house or `` maloca '' `` the maya elders say there is a great sickness coming to our planet ... everybody must rise up as one and no group must be left behind '' said `` wandering wolf '' a priest of guatemala 's maya quiche group at a ceremony to officially inaugurate the event late on friday in bogota `` wandering wolf '' a diminutive man with chiseled features is chairman of the inter-american council of elders an organisation said to have existed before europeans arrived in the americas and resurrected in guatemala in 1995 `` this is the time to bring out our great knowledge mother earth has told us to wake up mankind '' said marceliano guerrero of colombia 's huitoto community the core aim of the jungle reunion to be conducted away from the gaze of the media and curious onlookers is to work for harmony `` between man and mother earth '' said organiser francisco quiroga a mixed-race colombian the elders have said they will give a message to modern society in a last-ditch bid to stop the world `` spinning out of balance '' -- marking one of the first times in 500 years since columbus `` discovered '' the americas that they have broken their silence the meeting itself threatens to become a tower of babel english and spanish have been chosen as the main languages yet for many of the delegates neither language is their mother tongue and while the meeting will concentrate on the sacred prophecies of the elders some delegates are keen to discuss other politically-charged issues such as land rights and the defence of indigenous culture `` the u.s. government took away our land and assigned us places to live now we 're buying back land we owned in the 1800s the government also took our language away and made us learn the white man 's way '' philip largo a native american of the jicarilla-apache tribe from dulce new mexico told reuters even if the confederation of indigenous groups succeeds in drawing up a common message jose gabriel alimaco of the secretive kogi community from northern colombia 's sierra nevada doubts the white man or `` younger brother '' will listen `` we want to live in peace as brothers with the younger brother and for him to respect our land and sacred traditions alimaco said `` but the younger brother is creating great disorder and sickness ''

lebanon 's pro-iranian hizbollah on friday urged palestinians to kill their `` treacherous and tyrannical '' leadership for signing a peace deal with israel hizbollah party of god chief sheikh hassan nasrallah told a group rally in beirut that the palestinian people should `` overthrow this self-rule authority and execute its leadership '' the rally marked `` world qods jerusalem day '' the last friday of the moslem fasting month of ramadan dedicated to protests against the jewish state by iran 's late leader ayatollah ruhollah khomeini in 1979 nasrallah addressed the rally in beirut 's shi'ite moslem southern suburbs -- a bastion of the group -- where hundreds of hizbollah fighters marched on huge israeli and u.s. flags laid out in the street he said a palestinian khaled islmabouli was needed to make `` traitors of jerusalem pay a heavy price '' -- a reference to the egyptian islamist who assassinated egyptian president anwar sadat in october 1981 for signing peace with israel in 1979 a presenter introduced different guerrilla units including commandos in black uniforms and members of suicide squads with headbands and mock explosive packs `` it has become obvious that the real problem is in the tyrannical leadership of the palestinian people who will never break their chains of humiliation unless they punish and get rid of this treacherous leadership '' nasrallah said the palestinian authority -- headed by president yasser arafat -- signed an agreement for self-rule with israel in oslo in 1993 hizbollah guerrillas fight israeli troops to oust them from a 15 km nine miles -wide south lebanon occupation zone held by the jewish state since 1978

rain which blighted the england cricket team 's tour of south africa a year ago forced the abandonment of the opening match of their first trip to zimbabwe on saturday a spectacular thunderstorm forced the players off towards the end of the zimbabwe districts xi 's innings some 65mm of rain fell in an hour flooding the outfield the districts xi side containing six test players had made 198 for nine from 45.3 of their 50 overs when play was abandoned `` i was glad we fielded and at least had a run around in this heat and altitude '' said england coach david lloyd `` it gave everyone a decent workout at least '' the pick of the english bowlers was robert croft with figures of one for 34 from 10 overs alan mullally and ronnie irani took three apiece thanks to some good catching debutant chris silverwood betrayed nerves on his first appearance for england the 21-year-old yorkshire seamer bowled nine wides in a wayward spell england play a second one-day match against a president 's xi at the harare sports club on sunday

one of the most urgent tasks facing britain 's crushed conservative party is to restore its credibility in wales and scotland where it lost every single parliamentary seat for the first time in history the conservatives can not possibly hope to retake power from labour which won thursday 's general election by a landslide without gaining at least a few seats outside england to show they enjoy some support from all parts of the country but the scale of the challenge is huge since all the conservatives leading scots lost their seats the local hierarchy is in disarray and the party opposes the one policy which could help revive its support devolved government for scotland labour was always tipped to do well in the regions given the widespread dislike of the conservatives but did itself no harm by promising an element of devolution -- giving wales and scotland more say over their own affairs activists in scotland and wales have long chafed under the conservatives accusing the party of treating them as english vassals rather than separate entities `` the conservative party is now an english nationalist party whose electoral support is now almost entirely confined south of the tweed river bordering scotland and england and offa 's dyke on the welsh-english border '' said the guardian newspaper labour 's proposals although ground-breaking are in truth fairly modest -- each region would have its own parliament with limited rights to raise local taxes but only after the idea was approved by a referendum labour made clear that britain would stay united but the conservatives said devolution would split up the `` union '' of england scotland and wales and lead to separatism now they may well have to think again arnold kemp editor of the glasgow herald newspaper from 1981 to 1994 said the party had no choice but to drop its opposition to devolution `` the tories lack any moral authority in scotland the only route back is to acknowedge the inevitable '' he wrote in the evening standard newspaper david macletchie president of the scottish conservatives said opinion polls suggested scots cared little about devolution but he conceded the party might have to change its stance `` that 's a possibility and the matter has got to be tested in a very full debate which will focus on purely on that particular issue in the referendum '' he told bbc radio there is little evidence to suggest the scots or welsh want full independence judging by the performance of the parties which officially campaigned to make a clean break with england the scottish national party gained just six of the 72 scottish seats while plaid cymru `` the party of wales '' won only four of 40 welsh seats labour took the lion 's share with a few going to the minority liberal democrats the conservatives will still find it hard to restore their credibility if only because their new parliamentary spokesmen on scottish and welsh affairs will have to be legislators representing seats in england to make matters worse the party in scotland plunged into scandal just weeks before the election when chairman sir michael hirst resigned after allegations about his private life newspapers strongly hinted that the sources of the story had been hirst 's opponents inside the scottish conservative machine giving the impression of a party at war with itself a few days earlier allan stewart resigned his position as member of parliament in scotland 's safest conservative seat after reports linking him to a married woman and an clinic for recovering alcoholics but the news for the conservatives is not all bad although the vagaries of britain 's `` first-past-the-post '' voting system left them without any seats outside england they got half a million votes in scotland the full title of the party is the conservative and unionist party referring to the 1707 act of union which joined scotland to england to form the united kingdom wales had become part of england in 1536 reuter

a parcel bomb exploded in the storeroom of a home decoration shop in paris on thursday injuring one person rescue workers said the person 's life was not in danger they said the was no immediate claim of responsibility for the blast in the rue monge in paris latin quarter

second half substitute jozef majoros struck in the 84th minute to give slovakia an unexpected 1-0 win over 1994 world cup semifinalists bulgaria in a friendly on tuesday majoros slotted the ball past goalkeeper zdravko zdravkov after finding himself alone in front of goal the bulgarians looking for a good performance before their world cup qualifier against cyprus on april 4 rarely threatened to breach the slovak defence teams bulgaria 1-zdravko zdravkov 2-radostin kishishev 3-ivailo yordanov 4-milen petkov 5-gosho ginchev 6-zlatko yankov 7-emil kostadinov 8-anatoli nankov georgi antonov 84 9-dimcho belyakov georgi ivanov 46 10-marian hristov ivailo andonov 46 11-ilijan iliev georgi bachev 80 slovakia 1-alexander vencel 2-ivan kozak 3- miroslav karhan 4-marek spilar 5-igor balis 6-dusan tittel 7-samuel slovak peter dzurik 84 8-julius simon jozef majoros 46 9-tibor jancula stanislav varga 89 10-robert semenik miroslav sovic 46 11-lubomir moravcik vladislav zvara 69

german police freed a five-year old laotian girl unharmed in berlin on friday and detained four vietnamese on suspicion of kidnapping her the girl was abducted on tuesday from her home in the western town of neuss near duesseldorf by an armed gang which intitially held seven members of her family and demanded a ransom of tens of thousands of marks the gang then fled with the girl and a 36-year old woman police said the woman had also been found during the berlin operation security sources said they were investigating the possibility that she was in league with the kidnappers police said they believed the gang had been in berlin for several days the girl 's mother had been ordered to come to the city with a ransom of 60,000 marks police grabbed the vietnamese kidnappers as they tried to collect the ransom near an underground railway station in the lichtenberg district of the city

former tennis star ilie nastase has left politics in disgust after being defeated twice in bids for office on behalf of romanian president ion iliescu 's leftist party according to a statement released on thursday `` i had been dragged into a political quagmire '' nastase told romanian media in announcing his resignation from the party of social democracy pdsr `` my parents were right to tell me as a child that politics do not marry well with morality '' the one-time winner of the french open who returned home this year to seek a role in the balkan country 's politics was not immediately available for comment nastase lost a race for bucharest mayor in june and for a seat in parliament in november 3 polls when iliescu 's leftwingers were removed from government for the first time since the 1989 fall of communism the pdsr had picked nastase a national hero for his pranks on and off the courts in the 1970s in a bid to revive their sagging electoral fortunes instead he came under attack in the local press over his association with the president 's party `` nastase was great for sports but he does n't have the make of a politician '' pdsr campaign manager dan ghibernea told reuters `` politics is much tougher than sport '' iliescu faces a tough run-off battle to retain the presidency on sunday against a reformist challenger

the italian government said on tuesday mobsters had muscled in on the latest albanian exodus as bedraggled refugees described how they paid racketeers hundreds of dollars to cross the adriatic more than 8,000 albanian refugees have made the short sea crossing in a ramshackle flotilla of rusty boats over the past five days and united nations officials in geneva said the pace was picking up `` this is a business run by organised crime '' said giannicola sinisi undersecretary at the interior ministry who was in the south eastern region of puglia to monitor the situation the president of puglia 's regional council salvatore distaso called on the government to declare a state of emergency in the area saying it could not cope with the influx exhausted passengers reaching italy said they paid the equivalent of 600 each in the port of durres for places on jam-packed vessels and voyages to a new life abroad `` i paid and i would pay again if i had to '' said aljosha sulaj a 28-year-old businessman who said he had handed over the equivalent of around 3,000 for himself his wife his mother-in-law and their young son and baby daughter the average monthly wage in albania is around 65 `` to get to the port was not easy at every checkpoint there were people with guns who asked for money and i gave it to them then there was no problem getting near the boat '' he said reporters in durres said more vessels one without engines set off in the morning with hundreds of emigrants aboard the u.s. navy said on tuesday it had saved 20 albanian men who had been drifting in a boat in the adriatic sea for five days three of them without food and water a statement from a u.s. marine task force in the adriatic said the 20 men abandoned their powerless 25-foot vessel which was taking on water when a rescue boat from the cruiser leyte gulf pulled alongside late on monday afternoon it added that the group would be sent to brindisi chief anti-mafia prosecutor pier luigi vigna said he was worried that the influx of albanians would lift the crime rate as many of albania 's jails were empty after rioters stormed prisons and opened the gates `` the albanian mafia is running the boats in durres ... our worry is that apart from the albanian mafia albanian arms will come in too -- arms that will then become available to the italian mafia '' vigna told corriere della sera newspaper italy faced a crisis in 1991 when some 40,000 albanians commandeered rusting freighters and poured across the adriatic after the collapse of 45 years of stalinist rule it has since grappled with continuing problems of illegal albanian immigration and drugs and arms-smuggling prime minister romano prodi 's government says it will grant temporary sanctuary to genuine refugees from the armed chaos that has swept the country in an eruption of anger over the failure of shady saving schemes prodi called a cabinet meeting for wednesday to discuss how to cope with the latest wave of albanians to wash ashore makeshift reception centres in the southeast are full to capacity albanians are being moved to other regions and the mood of italians in the past two days has turned from sympathy to suspicion `` this is not a flight of the desperate '' la repubblica newspaper wrote `` this is the emigration of people who hope that they can seize the opportunity to get here and stay ''

these are the leading stories in the sarajevo press on wednesday reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy oslobodjenje bosnian companies which own holiday resorts along the adriatic coast in croatia can not use them until the problem of the ownership of bosnian companies in croatia and croatian companies in bosnia is resolved croatian tourism company official mili razovic says in an interview nato-led stabilisation force sfor stepped up its patrols on the former frontline between the croat and moslem-held parts of mostar in order to secure freedom of movement and safety of all the citizens moslem co-prime minister in bosnian government haris silajdzic meets the organisation for security and cooperation in europe osce chairman niels halvag petersen in sarajevo and says his government is not completely satisfied with the osce 's work in bosnia head of bosnia 's moslem-croat federation 's police department says that preparations for pope john paul 's visit to sarajevo scheduled for april 12-13 are carried out in a complex situation in the federation but the police is capable of providing security for all participants in the event bosnian serb officials held talks with the world bank 's officials and agreed that assistance to bosnian entities hinges on a deal with the international monetary fund imf prime minister of bosnia 's moslem-croat federation government edhem bicakcic says he requested greater contributions from the united states in deblocking the work of federal institutions and the establishment of the central bank the world bank is currently working on implementation of 16 bosnia projects worth a total of 360 million 210 million of which had allready been spent on the ground the bank executive director for central and eastern europe christine wallich says dnevni avaz if things continue to move this way there is a chance that dayton peace accord could be changed and we are doing our best to prevent that moslem co-prime minister in bosnian government haris silajdzic says officials from the u.s. embassy in sarajevo and the office of the international high representative for bosnia carl bildt think that the dayton peace accord must not be changed but implemented thouroughly the last mosque placed at the left bank of the neretva river in the croat held bosnian town of capljina has been damaged in an explosion set by bosnian croat extremists on march 10 town 's officials in exile say 19 suicides were registred in february on the territory of moslem-croat federation federal interior ministry says vecernje novine u.s. oil company amoco announces it will come to bosnia to check if it is rich with oil prime minister of bosnia 's moslem- croat federal government edhem bicakcic says after visiting the united states international supervision over the disputed bosnian town of brcko will begin on april 1 instead of march 22 the town 's official munib jusufovic says croatian president franjo tudjman and country 's defence minister gojko susak are not tearing bosnia apart croatian ambassador to bosnia darinko bago says -- sarajevo newsroom +387-71-663-864

four people were killed on thursday when unidentified gunmen opened fire on a bus in india 's troubled state of jammu and kashmir police said the gunmen suspected to be moslem militants fired indiscriminately on the moving bus near kashmir 's `` apple town '' of sopore 50 km 30 miles north of the state 's summer capital of srinagar police said more than 20,000 people have died in seven years of a separatist uprising in kashmir mainly hindu india 's only moslem majority region on tuesday unidentified militants exploded a bomb in a mosque in srinagar which killed four moslem worshipers waiting to end their day-long ramadan fast more than a dozen militant groups are fighting new delhi 's rule in kashmir

the interior ministers of algeria and tunisia met in algiers on sunday to discuss security issues the official algerian news agency aps said algeria 's mustapha ben mansour said the two neighbours needed to tackle the security issue `` more than ever '' algerian security forces have been locked in a five-year conflict with moslem fundamentalists during which about 60,000 people have been killed tunisian minister mohamed jegham who arrived in algiers on saturday and ben mansour stressed the need to strengthen bilateral relations aps said jegham visited the headquarters of security units and watched martial arts and self-defence exercises the agency said

east timorese roman catholic bishop carlos belo left dili on friday on his way to norway for the awards ceremony as co-recipient of the 1996 nobel peace prize witnesses said belo left the territory for the indonesian capital jakarta accompanied by five other people it was not immediately known when he would arrive in oslo the bishop will jointly receive the nobel award next tuesday with east timorese-born activist jose ramos horta who lives in self-exile in australia the indonesian government has condemned the inclusion of ramos horta in the award and foreign minister ali alatas said on friday that indonesia would not be represented officially at the ceremony in the norwegian capital `` i sincerely believe that this unfortunate choice in giving the honour to such a controversial figure as ramos horta ... will exacerbate the problem in finding a solution to east timor '' alatas said on friday he was responding to questions at a news conference called to discuss next week 's ministerial meeting of the organisation of the islamic conference oic in jakarta ramos horta has been a vocal leader of the opposition to jakarta 's rule in the territory belo and ramos horta were awared the prize for their efforts to secure a peaceful solution to the issue of east timor a former portuguese colony which indonesia invaded in 1975 and annexed the following year the united nations has never recognised jakarta 's move alatas said the government 's position on the nobel peace prize would have been different if it had been awarded solely to belo asked if the indonesian ambassador to norway would have attended the ceremony if only belo had been involved alatas replied `` probably yes but that is a hypothetical question '' alatas said on tuesday that on his way back from oslo belo would visit the vatican to see the pope and would also meet german chancellor helmut kohl in bonn kohl had wanted to meet belo during the chancellor 's official visit to indonesia last month but the bishop was too busy in east timor to come to jakarta

judges at the u.n. war crimes tribunal on monday adjourned a hearing on a croat 's appeal against his sentence of 10 years in jail for killing bosnian moslems at srebrenica drazen erdemovic last november became the first person to be sentenced by an international war crimes tribunal since the nuremberg and tokyo trials after world war two erdemovic who served in the bosnian serb army despite being a croat confessed to killing unarmed moslems from the u.n. `` safe haven '' of srebrenica in eastern bosnia in july 1995 saying he would have been killed had he not joined in the executions thousands of moslem men and boys went missing after the fall of srebrenica believed to have been systematically murdered by victorious bosnian serbs former bosnian serb president radovan karadazic and his military commander ratko mladic have been indicted in their absence by the u.n. tribunal for war crimes at srebrenica erdemovic appealed in december against his sentence with lawyers arguing that some facts were insufficiently established the killings had not been premeditated and that erdemovic had not been responsible because he was under extreme duress `` the judges have adjourned the hearing to make their decision after listening to the merits and demerits of the appeal '' a tribunal spokeswoman said `` there is no set time for them to deliver a decision ''

the leader of an independence uprising on papua new guinea 's bougainville island blamed png prime minister sir julius chan on tuesday for the crisis which has rocked his government bougainville revolutionary army bra political leader francis ona said chan had continually put pressure on the papua new guinea defence force to take firmer action against the bra which has waged a nine-year war for independence `` all along the prime minister of png has been pushing the png defence force who have already lost the war on bougainville '' ona told australian broadcasting corporation television chan on monday sacked his defence force chief brigadier-general jerry singirok after the army head called on the prime minister to resign over the hiring of mercenaries to help end the uprising on bougainville singirok had said the use of mercenaries called into question the sovereignty and credibility of his troops ona president of the rebels self-declared bougainville interim government said he had no plans to re-open talks to end the rebellion on the resource-rich island 800 km 500 miles north-east of port moresby `` i am not for negotiation i am straight out for independence '' he said `` negotiations will never get us anywhere '' he said ona said he believed chan 's recent efforts to end the bougainville fighting including the hiring of about 40 foreign mercenaries from british-based sandline international were intended to open the island for mining `` there are five mining companies ready to be set up on the island which means total wipe-out of the all the environment on bougainville '' ona said `` the only solution i would see is for the total withdrawal of png forces from the island ... and for some kind of mechanism so that bougainvilleans can decide for themselves the political future of bougainville '' he said guerrillas on the island have been fighting papua new guinea troops since 1988 after landowners demanded greater compensation for damage caused by the open-cut panguna copper mine the dispute flared into a secessionist uprising that closed the mine the following year and has claimed thousands of lives through fighting or disease -- british prime minister john major will make a three-day visit to bangladesh next month that officials here said would open a new horizon in bilateral relations between the two countries the official bss news agency said on thursday that major would arrive on january 10 and meet with prime minister sheikh hasina and other political leaders `` the visit has a special significance since this will be the first meeting between the two leaders '' bss quoted an official statement as saying major will be the first british prime minister to visit bangladesh since james callaghan in 1978 the statement said relations between the two countries had been `` excellent '' and that britain the second biggest export market after the united states remained a potential source of foreign investment in bangladesh bangladesh exported goods worth 128 million pounds sterling mostly apparel to britain in the first half of 1996 and imported 33.5 million pounds in goods from britain more than 45 british companies have investments in bangladesh britain 's cairns energy plc is engaged in gas exploration in the bay of bengal and midland power international has signed a memorandum of understanding for investment in private power generation projects here major will be accompanied by his wife norma

these are some of the leading stories in the jordanian press on wednesday reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy al-rai crown prince hassan calls for a broad definition of the term security says `` can not imagine middle east peace progress without the implementation of the hebron accord and pushing ahead on the syrian and lebanese tracks '' jordanian-israeli ministerial trade committee meets on wednesday to discuss the expansion of customs exempted goods and means of eliminating hurdles to jordanian-palestinian trade ad dustour prime minister kabariti 's meeting with the iraqi trade minister pushes stock market activity and prices rise campaign against israeli industries exhibition escalates al-aswaq king hussein visits the united arab emirates on saturday a joint jordanian-dutch business council to be set up jordan times jordan stresses need to bring old `` mideast into new world '' reminds israel that peace needs to be built on exchange of land for peace israel to allow jordanian trucks to carry cement to palestinians

a dying rebel indian woman set out on thursday from her dirt-poor village in southern mexico toward the bustling capital -- a journey that casts her as an unlikely symbol of the zapatista rebellion against mexico 's government stricken with cancer the diminutive tzotzil woman was the surprise solution to 11th-hour talks between the government and rebels over their plans to attend an indian congress in mexico city despite government warrants for their arrest government officials had also warned that a zapatista trip to the seat of government power would signal the end of peace talks that have dragged on-and-off since the rebels launched their january 1994 uprising `` she is the most belligerent aggressive and intransigent member of the zapatista army for national liberation '' charismatic rebel leader subcommander marcos told reporters and supporters in this remote village on wednesday in announcing that the woman would represent the rebels at the conference `` before dying she wished to speak with other indians '' he said wearing a trademark rebel ski-mask to hide her identity ramona -- her nom-de-guerre -- left in a car early on thursday escorted past makeshift army barracks by prominent mexican leftists and some members of congress her trip marks the first leg of a two-day journey that will take her to a modern city of 18 million that is unlike anything most of her villagers have ever seen she will represent her fellow rebels at the conference spreading the guerrillas gospel of indian autonomy to representatives of the country 's eight million indigenous peoples mexican newspapers on thursday said she could also seek medical treatment in mexico city the elderly infirm woman provided the zapatistas with a fitting symbol of their initial uprising which featured impoverished indians armed sometimes only with old rifles and machetes squaring off against mexican army tanks and planes the symbol of ramona as a modern-day david battling goliath was not lost on mexico 's press which called her choice as the zapatista envoy a shrewd public relations move ramona was to travel from the colonial city of san cristobal to mexico city on a chartered plane on friday in time for the conference 's final day on the anniversary of colombus arrival in the new world which is marked here with little celebration by indians her exit from the jungle marked the zapatistas symbolic break of a military stranglehold that was placed on them after their uprising thousands of troops have created makeshift barracks on the outskirts of the jungle in recent years creating pressure on the zapatistas to lay down their arms

british prime minister john major has ruled out holding an election on march 20 itn television said on thursday it quoted conservative party sources as saying he had ruled out the march date major said in an earlier interview that a parliamentary by-election due to take place on february 27 had to take place first before an election could be held if there was a march election the by-election would have to be cancelled `` i think people should just sit back and relax and not get overexcited about it for the moment '' major said the election must be held by may 22 and may 1 is hot favourite

police were searching on monday for the father of four children found shot to death in their beds on sunday night all of the children -- aged 10 13 14 and 16 -- were sleeping in a bedroom and were shot at least once in the head with a handgun police chief robin morse said the children 's mother bertha satterwhite found their pajama-clad bodies she also found a .22 calibre handgun beside a note addressed to her in the house authorities would not release the contents of the note she and her husband johnny satterwhite 36 separated a week ago a neighbour told police she last saw the children playing in the yard on thursday and heard the father 's pickup truck on friday no lights were on in the house all weekend she said

troops from france and the united arab emirates ended a week of joint military exercises on monday the official uae news agency wam reported senior army officials from both sides watched the exercises codenamed gulf 96 involving live ammunition jet fighters and an armoured offensive wam added over 600 french troops and 160 vehicles backed by 18 aircraft and three ships took part in the war games the largest such manoeuvre in the region this year involving french forces the french defence ministry said last week the uae which has signed a defence pact with paris is a major french arms client the gulf state has already purchased planes helicopters and tanks

the trial of 71 former ethiopian marxist officials accused of genocide and crimes against humanity resumed briefly on thursday after a 45-day break court officials said but the trial was immediately adjourned until next thursday after witnesses testified against former officials present in court only 46 of the former officials were in court on thursday the others including former leader mengistu haile mariam who lives in exile in zimbabwe are being tried in absentia all 46 have pleaded not guilty and face the death penalty if found guilty the former officials were members of the dergue the miltiary junta led by mengistu which ruled the horn of africa nation from 1974 after ousting emperor haile selassie until 1991 the prosecution presented five witnesses who said their relatives were arrested by marxist authorities on suspicion of being members of opposition groups they were later executed without trial a 44-year-old key prosecution witness told the court he was arrested by the miltiary in 1978 while working as head of the regional trade office at makale in north ethiopia on suspicion of being a member of a rebel group fighting to overthrow mengistu under ethiopian law witnesses in the trial can not be identified the witness told how some 1,500 government officials belonging to the tigrai ethnic group a rebel stronghold in those days were arrested in 1978 on grounds they backed the rebellion against mengistu they were repeatedly tortured `` because of the unbearable repeated torture many of us had to sign a false statement admitting that we were members of the rebel group the witness said many of those arrested were never seen again and are presumed dead he added the government says it holds 1,700 prisoners for alleged crimes under the dergue the only ones charged are those now on trial the rest have been held for up to five years without charge

west indies want cricket 's world cup to be staged every two years instead of every four years caribbean officials are also seeking to host the 2003 edition of the game 's most prestigious limited overs tournament the west indies cricket board wicb is to meet here on saturday to finalise plans for its bid ahead of an international cricket council icc meeting in malaysia next month said board secretary andrew sealy england are hosting the next world cup in 1999 and south africa have been awarded the 2003 event although the west indies are still challenging for it they are also pushing to host an earlier world cup if the icc approves a proposal to have the tournament every two years instead of every four sealy said on the caribbean news agency 's cana radio sports programme on tuesday `` the west indies have a two-fold attack basically `` we feel that we are entitled to the world cup in 2003 ... but outside of that fact we are also keen to have the world cup changed from every four years to every two years and we are suggesting that 2001 is when the next world cup could be held after 1999 '' at the icc meeting in malaysia the wicb 's position will be put forward by president pat rousseau vice-president julian hunte and chief executive officer steve camacho the wicb is `` cautiously optimistic '' the final decision over the 2003 venue not expected until the traditional full icc meeting at lord 's in july will be in its favour sealy said west indies proposal to host the world cup would feature a strong effort from various facets of the region and must not be seen as purely a wicb venture the last world cup was held in india pakistan and sri lanka 12 months ago and won by sri lanka

a private poll research agency on monday described thailand 's november 17 election campaign as the dirtiest and most violent since the mid-1970s when student-led democracy groups toppled thai military governments the rajapak institute said major political parties had resorted to blatant vote-buying political assassination and other electoral law violations in their campaigns in rural areas especially in northeast thailand `` this election is the messiest the worst in terms of electoral violations the most violent '' uthai dejatanond director of the rajapak institute 's northeast branch told a news conference `` these are acts that blatantly challenge democracy '' uthai did not single out any political party for leading electoral law violations but the northeast region is the stronghold of the new aspiration party nap headed by prime ministerial hopeful chavalit yongchaiyudh the rajapak institute predicted the nap may capture up to 70 of 137 lower house of representative seats up for grabs in the election it expected the democrat party led by former prime minister chuan leekpai to win as few as 13 seats in the region more than one third of the lower house 's 393 seats come from northeastern thailand preecha uatrakul a lecturer at the institute told reuters he believed the nap and other major parties -- democrat chart pattana and chart thai -- had all been involved in direct vote-buying the four parties have in the past week stepped up trading charges of vote-buying while current opposition parties the democrat and chart pattana have accused chavalit and prime minister banharn silpa-archa of chart thai of peddling influence `` one of the unfortunate facts is the party with the most money to dump in this election can buy thailand '' preecha said `` northeastern voters could not distinguish between good and bad politicians and election candidates fully exploit their priority for money '' preecha 's institute said that the average price of buying a vote in the northeast had risen to 200 baht 8 in the current poll from 50 baht in the past two elections seventeen people have been attacked by unidentified gunmen seven of them killed since campaigning began on september 27 police said campaign workers are usually prime targets for gunmen rather than candidates because they are better known and more influential locally than the politicians police said over the weekend banharn ordered police to step up efforts to curb violence ahead of the poll 1=25 baht

england 's top soccer league the premier league is close to signing a record-breaking deal for the television rights to foreign coverage of its matches the independent on sunday newspaper said the paper said the premier league 's chief executive rick parry `` is understood to be in negotiations to quadruple football clubs income from overseas tv rights to more than 20 million pounds 32.8 million '' it said parry was keen to complete the deal before april when he moves to a new job as chief executive at liverpool football club the paper said the league refused to confirm that talks were under way it said the deal would be worth close to 25 million pounds with around 20 million pounds going to the clubs after deductions -- giving qualifying clubs at least one million pounds a year for foreign rights to their games this compares with the 270,000 pounds a year each currently receives the paper added the observer said that under the current contract which is separate from a deal with british sky broadcasting to show live games in britain marketing rights to foreign tv companies are held by rome-based marketing and sponsorship agency csl a new contract is expected to be signed before the end of the current soccer season and would run until 2002 the new deal would not neccessarily be with csl with a number of other sports marketing agencies asked to tender for the rights it said

jose ayala lasso u.n. high commissioner for human rights has accepted a government invitation to visit china a u.n. spokeswoman said on tuesday no date has been set for the trip whose object would be to continue the `` constructive dialogue '' with beijing on the human rights situation in china according to therese gastaut `` the dates and programme are being discussed '' gastaut told a news briefing in geneva `` the timing has not yet been decided it will certainly be this year in the months to come '' she added u.n. sources said they did not expect his mission to take place before the start of the u.n. human rights commission 's annual session in geneva on march 10 ayala lasso is making his fifth trip to rwanda next week in its annual report two weeks ago the u.s. state department accused china of effectively silencing all public dissent against the communist party and government last year the u.s. delegation is widely expected to co-sponsor a resolution on china at the 53-member forum beijing last year successfully quashed a u.n. resolution critical of its human rights record which expressed concern over continued reports of violations of fundamental freedoms it was the sixth year in a row that china managed to avert censure ayala lasso named to the new post three years ago attended the women 's rights conference in beijing in september 1995 the only u.n. special rapporteur investigator to gain entry to china was abdel-fattah amor a tunisian lawyer who went in november 1994 to look into religious intolerance in a report to the u.n. commission on human rights the following month he recommended that the constitution be amended to provide guarantees on freedom of religion

disarmament negotiators conceded defeat on thursday as almost three years of talks on a treaty outlawing all nuclear explosions ended in failure the 61-nation conference on disarmament cd whose efforts for a landmark comprehensive test ban treaty ctbt were blocked by india decided it could not even agree to report its failure to the u.n. general assembly but major powers said they would work quickly to revive the draft treaty and have it approved and opened for signature in new york next month despite india 's opposition `` the cd has now played out its string there 's nothing more this body can do on the treaty itself '' said u.s. disarmament ambassador stephen ledogar `` but noone 's interested here in consigning the treaty to the dustbin ... the story now is in new york '' india blocked the treaty at a negotiating committee last week and confirmed its veto on tuesday because it said the pact did not contain a clause committing the five declared nuclear powers to a timetable for nuclear disarmament one of three nuclear `` threshold states '' alongside pakistan and israel india complained that the treaty would simply maintain the divide between the nuclear `` haves '' and `` have nots '' conference member states had hoped that the negotiating committee 's report which only stated that no consensus had been reached on the pact could still be forwarded to the general assembly which asked the conference last year for a ctbt but iran and india both blocked that move with iran using complicated procedural manouevring to head off a clear decision in a first meeting on thursday all five declared nuclear powers -- the united states russia china britain and france -- support the idea of reviving the text and having it signed at the outset of the next session of the general assembly as originally envisaged but they will not take the lead role in pushing through the resolution in new york where the support of major non-aligned states is seen as crucial in getting the clear overall majority needed to have the treaty approved without any changes australia signalled on thursday that it was ready to sponsor the resolution and diplomats said an australian text was already circulating in geneva canberra was expected to publicly announce its intentions on friday `` we can not give up the opportunity is here now it will not last '' said australian ambassador richard starr `` we must grasp it or lose it and with it the whole critical step towards nuclear disarmament '' the idea of sending the negotiating report to new york was supported on thursday by a number of influential non-aligned states including pakistan mexico brazil egypt peru and chile -- the states whose support will be crucial in new york

lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their thursday editions reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy lietuvos rytas newspaper sources said that the temporary administrator of innovation bank romualdas visokavichius might be appointed the new head of lithuanian savings bank finance minister algirdas shemeta said earlier that changes are pending in the managment of the state-run bank health care minister juozas galdikas expects that the new health insurance law will come into effect on july 1 thomson bankwatch granted a bb credit rating to lithuania vilniaus bank and hermis bank one notch higher than the previous rating respublika the lithuanian government failed to reach an agreement on issuing state guarantees for 200 million in credits for the building of the butinge oil terminal the conflict in the ministry of culture continues and four more experts resigned in protest at the administrative style of the minister saulius shaltenis three vice ministers resigned earlier the bank of lithuania is to decide whether to extend the term of its 13.7 million million litas loan to tauras bank lietuvos aidas security department officials siezed the last parts of a cassette with 50 kilograms of radioactive uranium stolen from ignalina nuclear power plant a numer of suspects have been detained the prime ministers of the three baltic countries intend to issue a joint-statement in tallinn today ezpressing their readiness to join the eu -- andrius vilkancas vilnius newsroom +370 2 22 35 17

the u.s. secretary of the army togo west arrived in kuwait on tuesday as part of visits by senior officials and officers to american troops deployed close to the iraqi border west is due to meet with some of the about 4,600 u.s. ground forces deployed in kuwait and will hand them letters and parcels from relatives back home a military spokesman said west will leave kuwait before thursday 's thanksgiving holiday to visit other u.s. forces in the oil-rich region u.s. defence secretary william perry will visit the troops on friday as part of a globe-circling trip that will also take him to other gulf arab states bosnia and japan perry diplomats say is expected to discuss in kuwait the duration of the deployment of u.s. forces in the tiny state the troop deployment is up for review in mid-december in addition to some 1,200 soldiers who deployed in kuwait in august washington in september rushed an additional 3,000 ground forces to kuwait in a fresh standoff with iraq

two portuguese peacekeepers died and a third was seriously injured in a vehicle accident in eastern bosnia over the weekend the nato-led peace implimentation force said in a statement according to ifor the portuguese chaimite armoured personnel carrier rolled into a ravine while on patrol near visegrad in bosnian serb territory on sunday afternoon the three crew members were quickly flown to hospital but two died aboard the helicopter ifor named the dead as private ricardo manuel dorges souto and private francisco jose barradas private hugo alexandre da silva sousa was being treated at the french military hospital at rajlovac for injuries to his pelvis and feet

by gail appleson u.s. law correspondent an imprisoned political leader of the militant palestinian group hamas should be released because the u.s. government has failed to extradite him to israel his lawyer argued on tuesday in january mousa mohammed abu marzook gave up his fight against extradition from the united states his lawyer michael kennedy argued during a hearing in manhattan federal court that federal law required the u.s. government to surrender him to israel or release him no later than march 28 kennedy and federal prosecutors disagree on when a two-month time limitation began after marzook 's decision to drop his appeal of an extradition order prosecutors say the deadline is april 6 last year a federal judge ordered abu marzook extradited to israel and another judge confirmed the ruling in october although abu marzook initially appealed the rulings his lawyers withdrew the appeal on jan. 28 it is believed that israeli and american officials have been trying to find ways to avoid extraditing abu marzook to israel out of fear it would lead to violence assistant u.s. attorney baruch weiss told the court that marzook 's extradition is a sensitive matter and that israel wants all the time to which it is entitled `` it is no secret this request for extradition is now complicated by the ongoing peace process '' he said u.s. district judge denise cote ordered the two sides to submit briefs on the matter and set the next hearing tentatively for monday `` this is probably the first case in the annals of united states extradition practice where a person is ordered extradited and is willing to be extradited and the government refuses to extradite or release him for political reasons preferring instead to keep him confined in perpetual limbo in federal jail '' marzook 's petition for release states in 1995 israel announced it had formally asked the united states to hand over abu marzook alleging he was responsible as the head of hamas 's political arm for attacks that killed scores of israelis israel did not contend that abu marzook personally committed any of the violent acts but charged he was criminally liable because of his high-level role in allegedly directing controlling and financially supporting hamas 's activities abu marzook has denied involvement in any violence he was arrested on july 25 1995 at a new york airport as he flew to the united states -- where he had lived for many years -- after immigration officials found his name on its `` watch list '' of people with `` known or suspected ties to terrorist activities '' israel had requested his arrest and his extradition alleging that the u.s.-educated gazan was involved in a number of fatal bombings shootings and stabbings between 1990 and 1994 and has raised money for and controlled the leadership of the military wing of hamas abu marzook has a home and business in virginia but u.s. and israeli authorities charged he frequently travelled to the middle east to promote violence and undermine peace efforts

the schengen executive committee on thursday firmed up plans to admit the five countries of the nordic passport union by the end of the year the ministers reached political agreement on full membership terms for european union members denmark sweden and finland and associate membership for norway and iceland which are outside the eu luxembourg justice minister marc fischbach said `` it was possible to reach a political agreement among all the delegations on the terms '' fischbach told a news conference seven full members of the zone -- france the netherlands belgium luxembourg portugal spain and germany -- dropped airport passport checks for each others nationals on march 26 1995 when schengen came into effect the accord named after the luxembourg town in which it was signed quickly fell short of expectations after france in deep disagreement with the netherlands over drugs policy refused to drop land border checks as planned on july 1 1995 fischbach said france had indicated on the sidelines of the meeting that it would take several months to finalise an accord with the hague on drugs policy which would allow it to drop the land border checks with belgium and luxembourg paris accuses the two countries of being transit points for dutch drugs the agreements with the five nordic countries will now be finally signed when the ministers next meet in luxembourg on december 19 fischbach said talks had been complicated as the two non-eu members norway and iceland will have to apply some parts of eu legislation for example on asylum and visa policy three other signatories who are not yet fully implementing the accord -- italy austria and greece -- vowed at the meeting to be fully on board in 1997 although a specific date was not set they have to pass data protection laws and make sure their external borders are properly policed the expansion has financial implications for the schengen accord its schengen information system computer system -- seen as essential to the common fight against crime -- was only conceived for five countries and will now have to admit 15 fischbach said adding a second computer might be necessary the computer contains among other things lists of people considered undesireable to help in processing visa applications and preventing illegal immigration in the border-free zone the rest of the eu is eyeing schengen as a possible model for a border-free zone in the union as a whole the eu has stalled at dropping border checks fearing it will become a playground for organised crime

work began on sunday to restore the murals on a mile-long segment of the berlin wall the longest piece left of the despised cold war symbol of division the so-called east side gallery -- a 1.6 km-long piece of the wall that was transformed into a mosiac of murals by more than 100 artists in 1990 -- was falling into disrepair before badly needed touch-up work began on sunday about fifteen of the original 118 painters from around the world who turned a stretch of the grey border into a collection of murals on the theme of the fall of the wall returned for the start of a ten-day effort to restore their work known as the world 's largest open air mural the east side gallery near the main train station in east berlin has been worn down by the elements and smeared with graffiti in the years since its creation in 1990 the murals reflect the euphoria of the period immediately after the wall opened on november 9 1989 they show arms extending through the image of a crumbling wall for a hand-shake east german trabant cars driving through to west berlin and scenes of the world peacefully uniting `` it is especially important to save the wall now because in 30 or 40 years it will only be a memory '' said artist kani alavi who organised the restoration `` we want to use the wall to keep memories of this time alive for the next generation '' the international group of artists was unable to obtain any funding for the restoration work from the city of berlin which is struggling to close enormous budget deficits many city officials want the wall -- which stands on a choice piece of land -- torn down a small ceremony at the start of the renovation work on sunday was also marred when a vandal rushed towards artists gerhardt and anne lahr and threw a can of red paint at the artists and their mural `` i guess you always have to deal with such aggression '' anne lahr said afterwards `` for an outdoor gallery it is normal that the work can not really be protected '' she added `` we will always have to return to restore this work because it is out here on an open street '' but at least one artist seemed not to mind the ravages of time irena dubrowskaya one of four muscovites who worked on the paintings in 1990 said she has enjoyed watching the city leave its mark on her work `` this painting was n't meant to last forever '' she said

american world champion maurice greene suffered his second defeat over 100 metres since his athens triumph on saturday and complained of feeling drained of energy greene who finished behind namibia 's frankie fredericks in zurich on wednesday in his first major race since his 100 win at this month 's world championships could not match the strong finish of compatriot tim montgomery and had to settle for third at the monaco grand prix with a 0.4 metre-per-second wind behind his back world bronze medallist montgomery clocked 9.99 seconds ahead of second-placed american dennis mitchell who ran 10.05 greene finished one hundreth of a second further behind in third on a warm evening on the cote d'azur which was perfect for sprinting the pressure was off the american after fredericks decided to run the 200 here and olympic champion donovan bailey was not competing but the 23-year-old american will need to win races like this before he can claim to be the leading 100 metres sprinter in the world he left the track shaking his head `` today i 'm very tired '' greene said `` i have been training very hard for the last two years '' montgomery added `` i ran a much better race than in athens and i felt much more relaxed no pressure so a better race it 's simple '' fredericks who missed out on the medals in the athens 100 and was second behind trinidad 's ato boldon in the 200 took revenge when he beat boldon over 200 with a time of 19.93 faster than the winning time of 20.04 in athens boldon could not live with fredericks 's stamina and speed in the final 20 metres and slowed up at the finish to take second in 20.11 the namibian pointed his finger at the crowd at the end as if to say 'i told you so `` in athens i was injured so i could n't do what i wanted '' fredericks said american marion jones the women 's world sprint champion who also lost her first 100 race since athens to veteran merlene ottey in zurich bounced back with a victory over the jamaican in the 200 metres in 21.92 ottey closed on the american in the last 50 metres but could only take second in 22.06 one of the most impressive performances of the night came from kenya 's world 5,000 metres champion daniel komen who stepped down to 1,500 and beat several olympic champions including spain 's fermin cacho and algeria 's noureddine morceli in a victory in three minutes 29.46 seconds the 21-year-old komen who decided to pull out of a bid to break the 3,000 metres world record here because he was disappointed by his 5,000 defeat in zurich proved emphatically that he has the speed for the shorter race at the end komen outsprinted burundi 's venuste niyongabo the olympic 5,000 champion who took second in 3:30.47 cacho the 1992 olympic champion who won silver at last year 's atlanta olympics and broke briton steve cram 's 12-year-old european record in zurich with a time of 3:28.95 could only finish fourth in 3:31.64 with morceli back in 12th in 3:33.98 denmark 's former kenyan wilson kipketer who smashed seb coe 's 16-year-old 800 metres world record in zurich when he clocked a historic one minute 41.24 seconds was clearly not in record-breaking mood although he won in a quick 1:42.77

israel pulled out of plans for a middle east summit in cairo last week because egypt set conditions to ensure it would succeed a senior egyptian official said in an interview published on thursday osama el-baz political adviser to president hosni mubarak also told the english-language newspaper al-ahram weekly that israeli prime minister benjamin netanyahu suffered from `` a combination of ideological rigidity and a lack of experience '' a change in israeli government policy would probably have to come through domestic pressure he added mubarak tried last week to arrange a meeting between netanyahu and palestinian president yasser arafat but his plans collapsed after u.s. president bill clinton joined in and announced plans for an alternative summit in washington `` the israelis wanted very much for egypt to host the summit but they retreated after learning that egypt is asking for certain requirements in order to guarantee the success of the conference '' said baz `` it 's only natural that if you host a meeting you want certain indications it will be successful because you are not a catering service this is a political meeting ... .otherwise there is no point '' he added egyptian officials have faulted the united states for not making adequate preparations for the washington summit which ended on wednesday without agreement on any substance baz said the policies of the new israeli government were a dead end `` no arab is going to accept them or tolerate them ... no statesman can maintain this view while seeing that the only thing it will lead to is bloodshed '' he said `` it would be a mistake for the arabs to think of israel as a monolithic structure that all israelis are the same because there are deep divisions inside israel `` israeli public opinion can force the new israeli government to change its course because israel can not be pressured from abroad it has to come from inside what 's important is that the government changes its course not that it falls '' he added asked to comment on netanyahu 's mentality he said `` it is a combination of ideological rigidity a hard line which is expressed in certain logical terms from their point of view and a lack of experience it 's not a question of political naivety but a matter of not knowing how far things can go what can work and what ca n't ''

u.n. secretary general kofi annan will visit president nelson mandela on friday to discuss their joint initiative to end the conflict in indonesian-ruled east timor officials said on monday foreign ministry spokesman pieter swanepoel said south africa was told on monday that annan and not a u.n. envoy would arrive for the midday meeting in pretoria government sources said annan 's surprise decision probably signalled an acceleration of the u.n. 's bid to end the conflict in east timor in pretoria the portuguese embassy confirmed in a statement on monday that south africa had expelled portuguese ambassador vasco valente last week in response to indonesian protests about a letter that went astray `` the south african authorities alleging a misunderstanding between the portuguese embassy and the south african presidency last friday august 1 requested the departure from pretoria of ambassador vasco valente '' the statement said `` the ambassador who had been due to leave pretoria at the end of august returned to lisbon the next day '' it added saying portugal regretted the decision two south african government sources said lisbon had been given 48 hours to withdraw valente after it was confirmed he had received and failed to forward or return a letter from mandela to indonesian president suharto which was delivered to his embassy by mistake `` there has been a slight mistake on the part of one individual and he has been asked to leave '' said one source adding that diplomatic relations with portugal remained intact in the letter mandela asked suharto to release jailed rebel leader xanana gusmao as a first step towards ending the conflict in east timor a former portuguese colony of which indonesia has taken control details of the letter were published in portuguese newspapers before suharto knew of its existence undermining mandela 's effort to assist the u.n. 's peace initiative joel netshitenzhe mandela 's senior spokesman earlier declined to confirm or deny that valente had been expelled but added `` the matter has now been resolved and the letter has been received by the indonesian president and government the process that president mandela initiated is proceeding smoothly '' east timor is the third international conflict in which mandela has sought personally to intervene he has tried to help bring democracy to nigeria and sought to mediate a peaceful transfer of power in the former zaire now the democratic republic of the congo mandela visited suharto last month and won permission to meet jailed rebel leader xanana gusmao after his return he wrote to suharto asking for the rebel leader 's release and inviting the indonesian president to south africa in november he also invited east timorese bishop and nobel peace laureate ximenes belo to visit him in south africa valente was the first foreign diplomat expelled since 1994 when mandela won the country 's first democratic elections presidential spokesman parks mankahlana said mandela would discuss with annan ways to bolster the u.n. 's initiative for peace in east timor `` the president is doing everything within the parameters of the u.n. mandate on east timor everything he is doing is designed to underpin the u.n. initiative '' he said `` the president really sees this as a medium to long-term effort it is not something that can be resolved quickly '' he said mankahlana said it was annan 's decision to visit mandela in person and not to send an envoy as originally planned

the last member of the so-called ochoa clan of colombian drug traffickers still in prison regained his freedom on monday after less than six years behind bars authorities said fabio ochoa vasquez 36 and the youngest of three brothers who shot to notoriety through their exploits with the violent medellin drug cartel was released from the itagui prison in northwest colombia on monday afternoon prison officials said before climbing into an armour-plated mitsubishi jeep and speeding away from the jail ochoa told reporters he had no fear of extradition to the united states and planned to devote the rest of his life to raising his children `` i believe in colombian laws '' he said apparently referring to the country 's five-year-old ban on extradition his release followed that of his oldest brother jorge luis ochoa vasquez on july 5 and juan david ochoa on july 29 all three had been held in the itagui prison on the outskirts of medellin and all served less than six years behind bars the three purported multi-millionaires who once topped wanted lists worldwide were given light prison sentences because they surrendered and confessed to drug-related crimes they were considered leading members of the medellin cartel headed by pablo escobar the notoriously violent drug boss who was gunned down by police in december 1993 a policy of short prison sentences for top colombian traffickers was introduced under president ernesto samper 's predecessor cesar gaviria it is known as `` the policy of submission '' and has been severely criticised by the united states samper has vowed to stiffen penalties for traffickers in legislation pending before congress but the reforms have been dismissed as too little too late by u.s. drug experts juan david ochoa has been linked by u.s. drug agents to the february 1986 killing in baton rouge louisiana of barry seal a medellin cartel associate who became a valuable informant for the u.s. drug enforcement administration no murder charges were ever filed against juan david and none of the ochoa brothers were held directly responsible for the campaign of bombings assassinations and kidnappings that escobar waged in the late 1980s and early 1990s the bloody campaign was unleashed to press the government into banning the extradition of drug lords to the united states -- a prohibition that was written into colombia 's consititution in 1991

palestinian protesters threw petrols bombs and rocks at israeli troops who responded with rubber bullets and teargas in hebron on saturday in a second day of fierce clashes in the west bank city hospital officials said at least 15 arabs were wounded by rubber bullets along what is becoming a confrontation line dividing the palestinian and israeli-controlled areas of the city hundreds of arab youths shouting `` allahu akbar '' god is greatest ran past palestinian police who tried but failed to stop them and hurled petrol bombs and rocks at israeli soldiers as the violence spread to several hebron streets witnesses said the clashes were as heavy as those on friday when at least 13 arab youths were injured by rubber bullets and dozens were treated for teargas inhalation in the most serious unrest since israel handed most of hebron to palestinian rule in january tension has been high since israel 's right-wing prime minister benjamin netanyahu sent bulldozers last tuesday to a hill between jerusalem and bethlehem to begin a new jewish settlement in occupied west bank on friday a palestinian suicide bomber killed three women in a crowded tel aviv cafe the militant moslem group hamas claimed responsibility and israel closed off the west bank and gaza the israeli army declared a curfew on friday on the israeli-controlled section of hebron where 400 jewish settlers guarded by the army live among thousands of palestinians an army spokesman said the curfew barred palestinians not israelis from moving around in the area

an indian playwright on thursday called the partition of british india 50 years ago and the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of people that followed possibly the greatest tragedy in history `` the partition of india in 1947 remains perhaps the greatest tragedy in world history '' gursharan singh a left- wing sikh punjabi writer told reuters in this northern city as india and pakistan celebrated a half century of freedom from colonial rule singh was an 18-year-old in the pakistani city of multan on august 15 1947 when largely hindu india won independence moslems had formed pakistan a day earlier `` communal riots were going on while my father decided to stay on in multan my mother elder sister and i moved to amritsar in a caravan of buses '' singh said at the city of amritsar just 100 km 62 miles from the pakistani city of lahore hindus and sikhs helped each other but moslems still remaining behind were targeted for attack `` i was eyewitness to an incident when moslem girls were forced to remove their clothes and paraded on the street at the instance of some sikh leaders '' singh said `` it was only when a group of hindu and sikh women lodged a strong protest that the moslem girls were allowed to wear their clothes and return to their places '' as jam-packed trains ferried hundreds of thousands of people back and forth across the border there were tales from both sides of religious bigotry and terrible deeds historians say hundreds of thousands died during the partition that saw six million people cross a newly formed border many left for a new homeland carrying nothing but mournful memories counting the dead was considered futile conservative estimates put the number of killed in partition riots at 500,000 others believe up to a million may have died at a refugee camp young inhabitants in an unfamiliar city helped old people whose children had gone looking for a livelihood to faraway cities like delhi singh recalled `` imagine more than one million people were killed in the name of religion just because a small group of political leaders decided that there should be two countries instead of one united india '' singh said

the following is a chronology of events in the o.j simpson double-murder case 1994 june 13 the bodies of nicole brown simpson and her friend ronald goldman are found outside her townhouse o.j simpson returns from chicago and is questioned by police june 16 victims are buried in separate ceremonies june 17 simpson is arrested after nationally televised slow-speed chase along los angeles freeways june 20 simpson pleads not guilty june 30 simpson 's preliminary hearing begins july 8 judge orders simpson to stand trial july 20 simpson offers 500,000 reward for information leading to the `` real killer or killers '' goldman 's mother sharon rufo files wrongful death lawsuit against simpson july 22 simpson pleads `` absolutely 100 percent not guilty '' at his arraignment case assigned to judge lance ito sept. 9 los angeles district attorney 's office says it will not seek death penalty against simpson sept. 26 jury selection begins 1995 jan. 11 jury sequestered jan. 24 opening statements begin feb. 3 denise brown takes the witness stand to testify about simpson 's alleged abuse of her sister feb. 12 jury tours crime scene and simpson 's mansion march 9 detective mark fuhrman takes the witness stand to testify about finding bloody glove at simpson 's estate may 5 goldman 's father fred goldman files wrongful death lawsuit against simpson may 12 nicole 's simpson 's father louis brown files a wrongful death lawsuit against simpson for his daughter 's estate june 15 simpson tries on bloody gloves in court and pronounces them `` too small '' july 6 prosecution rests case july 10 defence begins its case aug. 29 portions of taped interviews with fuhrman played in court in which he is heard uttering racial slurs sept. 6 taking the witness stand with jury absent fuhrman asserts constitutional right against self-incrimination and refuses to answer questions sept. 22 simpson proclaims his innocence in a surprise courtroom statement both sides rest sept. 25 closing arguments begin sept. 29 case is handed over to jury oct. 2 jury reaches verdict after less than three hours of deliberations ito says verdict to be read next day oct. 3 simpson is acquitted and set free 1996 jan. 22 lawyers for plaintiffs begin taking simpson 's sworn deposition for civil case jan. 25 in first full post-trial tv interview simpson tells a black entertainment television reporter that he is innocent july 17 judge alan haber who presided over pre-trial issues is removed from case at request of simpson 's lawyers july 23 judge hiroshi fujisaki assigned to preside over civil trial aug. 13 fujisaki imposes sweeping gag order on trial participants aug. 23 fujisaki bans all cameras from courtroom sept. 17 civil trial begins sept. 18 jury selection starts oct. 23 openings statements begin with goldman family attorney calling simpson a `` vengeful killer '' nov. 22 simpson begins testifying

text: moskau reuter bei einem bombenanschlag vor einem bürogebäude im zentrum moskaus ist am freitag nach polizeiangaben ein geschäftsmann getötet worden der sprengsatz sei explodiert als der mann aus seinem auto gestiegen sei zwei leibwächter seien schwer verletzt worden die nachrichtenagentur interfax berichtete unter berufung auf sicherheitskreise bei dem getöteten habe es sich um den stellvertretenden chef eines handelsunternehmens gehandelt bei dem opfer seien dokumente gefunden worden die ihn als einen unterstützer des nationalisten wladimir schirinowski auswiesen berichtete interfax die polizei ziehe mehrere tatmotive in betracht dak/law c reuters limited 1997

guatemala reuter der präsident guatemalas alvaro arzu hat den hinterbliebenen des unglücks im fuballstadion von guatamala-stadt schmerzensgeld versprochen er habe deshalb die stadioneinnahmen beschlagnahmen lassen sagte er am donnerstag in einer fernsehansprache am mittwoch waren bei einer massenpanik vor dem wm-qualifikationsspiel guatemala gegen costa rica über 80 menschen getötet worden arzu kündigte zudem eine gründliche untersuchung der ursachen an um solche katastrophen künftig zu vermeiden dazu sei eine regierungskommission gebildet worden die ihm bis anfang november bericht erstatten werde sagte er über die ursachen des folgenschwersten unglücks in der geschichte der fußballweltmeisterschaft herrscht noch unklarheit einige zeugen haben berichtet es seien noch zuschauer eingelassen worden als die tribünen schon überfüllt gewesen seien das deckt sich mit der beobachtung daß vor dem stadion gefälschte eintrittskarten verkauft wurden die offizielle version lautet bislang auslöser seien auseinandersetzungen zwischen den fans in der südkurve gewesen wo sich das unglück ereignete kjf c reuters limited 1996

moskau reuter rußland sollte nach ansicht von sicherheitsrats-sekretär iwan rybkin zunächst der politischen struktur der nato und später der miliärischen beitreten rybkin der erst im vergangenen monat zum sekretär von präsident boris jelzins sicherheitsrat ernannt worden war sagte laut nachrichtenagentur interfax am dienstag nach der aufnahme in die politische struktur der allianz könne rußland auch in die militärorganisation eintreten wenn sich die dinge so entwickelten wie rußland es erwarte und die vertreter des westens es hofften rybkin vertrat damit eine klar gegensätzliche position zur bisherigen haltung des kreml gegenüber der nato es war zunächst nicht klar ob er seine persönliche meinung äußerte oder ob sich die haltung der russischen regierung gegenüber einer nato-erweiterung verändert hat rybkin verwies auf das beispiel frankreichs das zwar jahrelang nato-mitglied war aber seine truppen nicht dem gemeinsamen oberkommando unterstellt hatte rußland benötige noch zeit für eine volle nato-mitgliedschaft da es die militärischen strukturen denen der allianz anpassen müsse sagte rybkin eju/gwa c reuters limited 1996

zagreb reuter die vereinten nationen uno haben die entscheidung kroatiens begrüßt den serben in ostslawonien minderheitenrechte einzuräumen der chef der uno-übergangsmission in ostlawonien untaes jacques klein sagte am montag in zagreb das beschlossene dokument werde die abhaltung von wahlen in ostslawonien am 16 märz erleichtern klein hatte sich zuvor mit dem kroatischen präsidenten franjo tudjman getroffen das uno-mandat läuft am 15 juli ab in ostslawonien leben 120.000 serben die hälfte von ihnen sind flüchtlinge aus gebieten die kroatien 1995 von den serben zurückerobert hatte das memorandum war am samstag von einer kroatischen parlamentsdelegation vorgelegt worden aus kreisen der regierung in zagreb und der uno verlautete auf wunsch der serben seien nachträglich veränderungen vorgenommen worden so seien jetzt zwei mandate für die serben in oslawonien im kroatischen parlament vorgesehen ursprünglich sollten sie nur einen sitz erhalten das memorandum sieht außerdem vor daß die serben dort wählen dürfen wo sie vor kreigsausbruch im jahr 1991 gelebt hatten es erlaubt darüber hinaus das recht auf kriegsdienstverweigerung aus gewissensgründen der kommandeur der nato-truppen in europa us-general george joulwan hat unterdessen in washington landminen als eine hauptsorge der friedenstruppe in bosnien bezeichnet ihre räumung dauere länger als angenommen zudem gebe das militärische potential der polizeikräfte der früheren bürgerkriegsparteien anlaß zur bersorgnis die us-tageszeitung `` new york times '' hatte gemeldet einige polzeikräfte horteten möglicherweise mörser und andere waffen bek/ker c reuters limited 1997
